revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=December 2016}} Many songs, albums, bands and performances have referenced [[Donald Trump]] or his various brands, including [[Trump Tower]], his TV show, his hotel chain, and his casinos.<ref name="McCann, 2016" /> Though recent songs refer to Trump's campaign and subsequent election as [[President of the United States]], more than 200 songs refer to Trump prior to his successful presidential campaign between 1989 and 2013.<ref name="Bristout, 2016">{{cite web|last1=Bristout|first1=Ralph|title=38 rap references that display Donald Trump's fall from hip-hop grace|url=https://revolt.tv/stories/2016/11/02/38-rap-references-display-donald-trumps-fall-hiphop-grace-07003da490|website=Revolt TV|accessdate=November 13, 2016|date=November 2, 2016}}</ref> With his victory in the 2016 presidential election, Trump's prominence in hip-hop music has been likened to that of [[Ronald Reagan]]'s in [[hardcore punk]] during the 1980s.<ref name="Barshad, 2016">{{cite web|last1=Barshad|first1=Amos|title=The Joy Of "Fuck Trump": YG and some goofy kids from Baltimore have the Trump catharsis you need.|url=http://www.thefader.com/2016/04/06/yg-nipsey-hussle-anti-trump-rap-songs|publisher=The Fader|accessdate=November 13, 2016|date=April 6, 2016}}</ref>
==Background==
===Hip hop=== Trump's name first appeared in [[hip hop]] lyrics during the 1980s when the business mogul became an icon of the ultra rich. Among the earliest mentions of Trump in rap lyrics was the [[Beastie Boys]]' track "Johnny Ryall" on the 1989 ''[[Paul's Boutique]]'' album, in which they contrast Donald Trump with his homeless [[alter-ego]], Donald Tramp.<ref name="Bristout, 2016" />
While many rappers praise Trump's wealth, usually comparing their own financial aspirations or success to that of the billionaire businessman, others have used their music as a platform to criticize Trump's practices and politics.<ref name="Finley, 2015">{{cite web|last1=Finley|first1=Taryn|title=67 Times Rappers Name Dropped ‘Donald Trump’|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/hip-hops-25-year-obsession-with-donald-trump_us_55d61727e4b055a6dab3524a|website=Huffington Post|accessdate=November 12, 2016|date=August 20, 2015}}</ref> Among the earliest of these was [[The Coup (band)|The Coup]] from [[Oakland, California]], who critiqued and mocked Trump on their first two albums released in the early 1990s.<ref name="McCann, 2016" />
[[ESPN]]'s political site [[FiveThirtyEight]] documented that between 1989 and 2014, 19% of song lyrics about Trump were negative while 60% were positive. The 2010s marked a left-leaning political shift in musicians' attitude toward Trump as his presence in the public eye changed from that of a business tycoon to a politician, particularly one known for making controversial statements. Because of hip hop's close association with minority communities and its reinvigorated politicization with the [[Black Lives Matter]] movement, lyrical depictions of Trump rapidly grew to be more disparaging throughout his campaign and subsequent election as President of the United States.<ref name="McCann, 2016" />
Many artists have name-checked Trump in more than one song. Pre-presidency, [[Rick Ross]] had the most Trump mentions (nine songs between 2008 and 2015) with [[Nas]] running second (seven songs between 1996 and 2012). Other major Trump name-checkers include [[Migos]] (six songs between 2013 and 2016), [[Young Thug]] (six songs between 2013 and 2015), [[Lil Wayne]] (five songs between 2000 and 2012) and [[Raekwon]] (five songs between 1995 and 2012).<ref name="McCann, 2016" />
====Mac Miller controversy==== When [[Mac Miller]]'s 2011 song "[[Donald Trump (song)|Donald Trump]]" became a ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' hit, Trump released a [[YouTube]] video congratulating the rapper:
{{quote|A lot of people are calling me about the Mac Miller rap song. Now, it's named "Donald Trump." Maybe you should pay me a lot of money, but it just did over 20 million people, tuning into Mac Miller. So in one way, I'm proud of him. I haven't actually seen the language... Probably, it's not the cleanest language you've ever heard... But the "Donald Trump" song just hit over 20 million, that's not so bad. I'm very proud of him.<ref name="Zaru, 2015">{{cite news|last1=Zaru|first1=Deena|title=What hip-hop lyrics tell us about Donald Trump|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/09/02/politics/donald-trump-rich-hip-hop-lyrics-rap/|accessdate=November 26, 2016|publisher=CNN|date=September 2, 2015}}</ref>}}
As the song garnered more plays, Trump took a more aggressive tone and demanded [[royalties]] for using his name, thereby starting a feud with Miller.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Makarechi |first1=Kia |title=Mac Miller, Donald Trump's Least Favorite Rapper, Revisits Feud |url=http://www.vanityfair.com/news/2016/01/mac-miller-donald-trump-feud |accessdate=June 13, 2016 |work=Vanity Fair |date=January 25, 2016}}</ref> In early 2013, Trump threatened the rapper via a series of exchanges on [[Twitter]]:
{{quote|Little @MacMiller, you illegally used my name for your song “Donald Trump” which now has over 75 million hits. I want the money not the plaque you gave me! I’m now going to teach you a big boy lesson about lawsuits and finance. You ungrateful dog! I have more hair than you do and there’s a slight age difference.<ref name="Trump, 1/31/2015">{{cite web|last1=Trump|first1=Donald|title=@MacMiller|url=https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/297084584334589952?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw|website=Twitter|accessdate=November 26, 2016|date=January 31, 2015}}</ref>}}
In 2015 Trump changed his attitude toward Miller again when he ended an interview with ''[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]'' by praising Miller's song as it approached 100 million hits.<ref name="Cirilli, 2015">{{cite news|last1=Cirilli|first1=Kevin|title=Trump praises rapper’s ‘great’ song about him|url=http://thehill.com/blogs/in-the-know/in-the-know/248911-trump-praises-rappers-great-song-about-him|accessdate=November 26, 2016|work=The Hill|date=July 23, 2015}}</ref> Miller later appeared on ''[[The Nightly Show with Larry Wilmore]]'' to denounce Trump for [[Racial views of Donald Trump|his racial views]] during his run for President in 2016.<ref>{{Citation|last=Comedy Central|title=The Nightly Show - Mac Miller Unloads on Donald Trump|date=2016-03-10|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Zm8ISls_TBA|access-date=2018-10-03}}</ref>
===Other styles of music===
Outside of hip hop, most lyrical references to Trump have appeared in songs ranging from [[satire]]s of the billionaire, to outright protest in varying degrees of explicitness. One of the earliest Trump send-ups was the 1990 ballad "Donald Trump (Black Version)" written by [[Prince (musician)|Prince]] for fellow [[Minneapolis]] act [[The Time (band)|The Time]] in which singer [[Morris Day]] calls himself a black version of Donald Trump, who can use his riches to "fulfill [a woman's] every wish, [and her] every dream".<ref name="Jackson, 2016">{{cite news|last1=Jackson|first1=Lucas|title=Prince once wrote a song called "Donald Trump (Black Version)"|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/prince-once-wrote-a-song-called-donald-trump-black-version/|accessdate=November 22, 2016|agency=CBS News|publisher=CBS|date=April 22, 2016}}</ref> In 1992 Irish [[folk-rock]] group [[Goats Don't Shave]] had a #4 hit with "[[Las Vegas in the Hills of Donegal]]," which references Trump's [[casino]] business in imagining [[County Donegal|an Irish county]] that becomes a [[gambling]] mecca.<ref name="Donegal 2016" />
More recently, songs like "Fergus Laing" by Scottish folk singer [[Richard Thompson (musician)|Richard Thompson]] present thinly veiled references to Trump without mentioning him by name, while songs like "Fucked Up Donald" by Canadian punk band [[D.O.A. (band)|D.O.A.]] are more direct. Many songs attack Trump by mocking his supporters through stereotypical portrayals of their views and lifestyles. [[Phoenix, Arizona|Phoenix]]-based comedian Brian Nissen comedian stars as "Mullets Over America" spokesman Dwain in the music video "Make America Great Again", while Rocky Mountain Mike's cover of "[[Mr. Tambourine Man]]" remakes the lyrics to be about Trump, with the song's title alluding to the color of his skin. Sung from the perspective of a [[xenophobia|xenophobic]] Trump supporter, the song opens:
{{quote|Hey Mr. Tangerine Man, build a wall for me I'm not that bright and don't know that you're not going to Hey Mr. Tangerine Man, keep Muslims away from me With my jingoistic worldview, I'll come following you.<ref name="Hermann, 2016">{{cite news|last1=Hemann|first1=Andy|title=The 10 Best Trump Parodies and Protest Songs|url=http://www.laweekly.com/music/the-10-best-trump-parodies-and-protest-songs-7052391|accessdate=November 14, 2016|agency=L.A. Weekly|date=June 21, 2016}}</ref>}}
In October 2016, author [[Dave Eggers]] launched a project slated to release one anti-Trump song each day leading up to [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016's election day]]. Originally called ''30 Songs, 30 Days'', Eggers' plan was to have each song performed by a different artist, but due to more musicians coming through with songs, it grew to be 40, and then [[30 Days, 50 Songs|50 songs in 30 days]].<ref name="Kornhaber, 2016">{{cite web | url=https://www.theatlantic.com/entertainment/archive/2016/10/30-days-30-songs-donald-trump-death-cab-for-cutie/503783/ | title=Donald Trump Is Terrific Protest-Music Inspiration | work=The Atlantic | date=October 12, 2016 | accessdate=October 15, 2016 | author=Kornhaber, Spencer}}</ref><ref name="30 Days, 30 Songs">{{Cite web|url=http://www.30days30songs.com/about|title=About 30 Days, 30 Songs|last=|first=|date=|website=30 Days, 40 Songs|publisher=Artists for a Trump-free America|access-date=November 1, 2016}}</ref> Eggers worked on the project with [[Jordan Kurland]] with whom he had previously worked on two similar election-related projects.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.30days30songs.com/masthead|title=30 Days, 30 Songs: Masthead|last=Kurland|first=Jordan|date=|website=30 Days, 40 Songs|publisher=|access-date=November 1, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.zeitgeistmanagement.com/|title=Zeitgeist Artist Management|last=|first=|date=|website=zeitgeistmanagement.com|publisher=|access-date=November 1, 2016}}</ref><ref name="Cillizza, 2016">{{cite web | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2016/10/13/famous-musicians-are-writing-30-anti-trump-songs-for-the-final-30-days-of-the-election/ | title=Famous musicians are writing 30 anti-Trump songs for the final 30 days of the election | work=Washington Post | date=October 13, 2016 | accessdate=October 15, 2016 | author=Cillizza, Chris}}</ref> Eggers' inspiration for the project came when attending a Trump rally in [[Sacramento]] earlier that year.<ref name="Goodman, 2016">{{cite web | url=http://www.ew.com/article/2016/10/11/30-days-30-songs-dave-eggers-anti-trump-music | title=Inside the making of Dave Eggers' anti-Trump music project, 30 Days, 30 Songs | work=Entertainment Weekly | date=October 11, 2016 | accessdate=October 15, 2016 | author=Goodman, Jessica}}</ref> Participating artists included [[Death Cab for Cutie]], [[Aimee Mann]], [[Bhi Bhiman]], [[Jim James]], [[Franz Ferdinand (band)|Franz Ferdinand]], [[Josh Ritter]], [[Thao Nguyen]], [[EL VY]], [[R.E.M.]], [[Adia Victoria]], [[Moby]], [[Lila Downs]], [[Mac McCaughan]], [[Tim Bluhm]], [[Vinnie Paz]], [[Jesu (band)|Jesu]], [[Sun Kil Moon]], [[Filthy Friends (supergroup)|Filthy Friends]], [[Radioinactive]], [[Amuka|Sheila Brody]], [[Ani DiFranco]], [[Andrew Bird]], [[Mirah]], [[clipping.]], [[Sam Cohen (musician)|Sam Cohen]], [[Blake Hazard]], [[John Wesley Harding (singer)|Wesley Stace]], [[Loudon Wainwright III]], [[Cold War Kids]], [[Reggie Watts]], [[Mission of Burma]], [[Bob Mould]], [[Ryan Miller (musician)|Ryan Miller]], [[The Long Winters]], [[Open Mike Eagle]], [[Jimmy Eat World]], [[Kyle Craft]], [[Local Natives]], [[Anthony D'Amato]], [[Greg Holden]], [[Laura Gibson]], [[Tim Heidecker]], [[Modern Baseball]], [[Joe Purdy]], and [[Rogue Wave (band)|Rogue Wave]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.30days30songs.com/|title=30 Days, 30 Songs|website=30 Days, 30 Songs|access-date=November 26, 2016}}</ref>
In June 2017, Compound Sound LLC released ''Trumped Music'', a 32-minute album of eight songs which are [[Fair Use]] parodies of famous hit songs throughout the years. These songs are sung by impressionist Christopher John as 'Donald Trump', with several tracks also featuring impressionist Andrew Harris as 'Vladimir Putin'.<ref>{{cite web|title=Trumped Music|url=http://www.TrumpedMusic.com}}</ref>
===Opera=== At the 2017 [[Lowlands (festival)|Lowlands Festival]] in the Netherlands, the American [[coloratura soprano]] [[Sara Hershkowitz]] performed [[György Ligeti]]'s 1992 concert excerpts from his opera ''[[Le Grand Macabre]]'', titled ''Mysteries of the Macabre'', with the [[Noord Nederlands Orkest]]. She alluded to Donald Trump in three costumes which she changed on stage, a clown, baby outfit with a bottle, and a [[Miss America]] swimsuit.<ref>{{cite news |last = Axelrod |first = Toby |url = https://www.jta.org/2017/10/16/arts-entertainment/this-jewish-soprano-takes-on-trump-in-absurdist-opera-piece |title = This Jewish soprano takes on Trump in absurdist opera piece |work = Jewish Telegraphic Agency |date = 16 October 2017 |accessdate = 13 July 2018 }}</ref><ref>{{YouTube|id=Bq9xLVn6QgE|Sara Hershkowitz and the NNO perform Ligeti's Mysteries of the Macabre}}</ref>
==Songs that mention Donald Trump==
===1980s=== <!-- When adding a song to list, please include its date of release and a reference -->
* "Johnny Ryall" by [[Beastie Boys]] (1989): "Donald Trump and Donald Tramp living in the men's shelter" <ref name="Bristout, 2016" /> * "My Word Is Bond" by Donald D (1989): "And after that me and Donald Trump hung out / Donald talkin' 'bout Donald Trump,' man, y'all is crazy" <ref name="McCann, 2016" /> * "Trump" by [[Cindy Lee Berryhill]] (1989), from the [[Rhino Records]] album ''Naked Movie Star''.<ref>{{cite news|last=Arnold|first=Thomas K.|title=Motown Mover and Shaker Takes Stage at Fair Tonight|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1989-06-21/entertainment/ca-2376_1_motown-sound-motown-artists-del-mar-fair-s-grandstand|accessdate=September 1, 2017|work=Los Angeles Times|date=June 21, 1989}}</ref> *"Sick of You" by [[Lou Reed]] (1989) from ''[[New York (album)|New York]]'': "They ordained the Trumps and then he got the mumps..."<ref name="Song Bar, 2017">{{cite news |title=Lou Reed – Sick of You |url=http://www.song-bar.com/song-of-the-day/lou-reed-sick-of-you-new-york-donald-trump |accessdate=4 November 2018 |work=Song Bar |date=April 19, 2017}}</ref>
===1990s===
<!-- When adding a song to list, please include its date of release and a reference -->

===Pre-existing songs modified to be about Donald Trump===
* "Born to Die," a 1982 song by [[MDC (band)|Millions of Dead Cops]] begins with the chant "No war! No KKK! No fascist USA!" The chant was modified by American [[punk rock]] act [[Green Day]] at the 2016 [[American Music Awards]] to become, "No Trump! No KKK! No Fascist USA!" from there, the chant was taken to the streets by anti-Trump protestors.<ref name="Lynskey, 2017">{{cite news|last1=Lynskey|first1=Dorian|title=‘No Trump! No KKK! No fascist USA!’ – the punk chant that soundtracks the protests|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/shortcuts/2017/jan/31/no-trump-no-kkk-no-fascist-usa-green-day-punk-chant-protest-soundtrack|accessdate=31 January 2017|work=The Guardian|date=31 January 2017}}</ref> * "[[Mr. Tambourine Man]]" by [[Bob Dylan]] (1965) was reworded to "Mr. Tangerine Man" by Rocky Mountain Mike (2016).<ref name="Hermann, 2016" /> *"Fucked Up Donald" (2016) by Canadian punk band [[D.O.A. (band)|D.O.A.]] is based on their song "Fucked Up Ronnie" (1981).<ref name="Bickel, 2016">{{cite web|last1=Bickel|first1=Christopher|title=‘F*cked Up Donald": Punk Legends D.O.A. Eviscerate Donald Trump|url=http://dangerousminds.net/comments/fcked_up_donald_punk_legends_d.o.a._eviscerate_trump|website=Dangerous Minds|accessdate=November 13, 2016|date=April 29, 2016}}</ref> * "[[Sunday Bloody Sunday]]" a song by U2 contains the line "When fact is fiction and TV reality", but during U2's 2017 tour, [[Bono]] sung the lyrics "When fact is fiction and reality TV" in a reference to Trump's reality TV career.{{Citation needed|date=June 2018}} * While performing live at the [[Shoreline Amphitheater]] in 2017, [[Matt Bellamy]] of [[Muse (band)|Muse]] prefaced their performance of "Take a Bow" by saying: "''This next song was written back in 2006, I think. And I thought the president we had then was bad...but this song is much more relevant now than it was then.''"<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Qt3UYVZSjLc |title=Take A Bow- Muse (Shoreline Amphitheatre 9-15-17) |publisher=YouTube |date=2017-09-17 |accessdate=2018-03-14}}</ref> * "Control (Trump 45 Version)" by Dicepeople featuring The Brooklyn Foundation. In March 2018, London based dark electro band Dicepeople teamed up with Manchester's The Brooklyn Foundation for a remix of "Control", a track originally from Dicepeople's acclaimed 2011 album It Gets Darker. The new "Trump 45" version of the song was released exclusively as a new politically inspired video single.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Browne |first1=Paul |title=Dicepeople (Feat The Brooklyn Foundation) – Control |url=http://www.electricity-club.co.uk/dicepeople-feat-the-brooklyn-foundation-control/ |website=The Electricity Club |date=12 March 2018|accessdate=10 November 2018}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Ronald Reagan in music]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
{{Trump media}} {{Donald Trump}}
[[Category:Popular music]] [[Category:Hip hop]] [[Category:Songs about Donald Trump|*]]

revision.comment: added [[Category:2010 songs]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox single <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Songs --> | Name = En tus Tierras Bailaré | Cover = | Alt = | Artist = [[Wendy Sulca]], [[Delfin Quishpe]] and [[Tigresa del Oriente]] | Album = | Released = {{Start date|2010|04|19}} | Format = | Recorded = | Genre = [[Electropop]], [[Andean music]] | Length = 4:22 | Label = | Writer = | Producer = Gaby Kerpel | Last single = | This single = | Next single = }} '''En Tus Tierras Bailaré''' (English: "In your lands I will dance") is a [[Spanish language]] [[viral video]] that celebrates love for the land and people of [[Israel]]. It appeared in April 2010.<ref name=Carmon>[http://www.tabletmag.com/life-and-religion/38292/viral-zionism/]"Viral Zionism; How an Israel-promoting web-video phenomenon bloomed in Latin America", Irin Carmon, July 2, 2010, Tablet magazine.</ref>
The song received attention in Latin American rapidly got millions of hits.<ref name=Tiempo>[http://www.eltiempo.com.ec/noticias-cuenca/39702-contina-a-el-a-xito-de-delfa-n-quishpe/ Diario El Tiempo, Ecuador]</ref> [[Calle 13 (band)|Calle 13]] singer Residente called it [[YouTube]]'s "[[We Are the World]]".<ref>[http://elcomercio.pe/noticia/465296/vocalista-calle-13-destaco-twitter-video-tigresa-oriente Diario El comercio, Peru]</ref>
==The singers==
The video features three principals and a number of back-up singers. The principals are [[Peru]]vian [[singer]]s [[La Tigresa del Oriente]], [[Wendy Sulca]] and Indigenous Kichwa [[Ecuador]]ian singer-songwriter [[Delfin Quishpe]], known as ''"Delfín Hasta El Fín"''. Quishpe has expressed a desire to visit Israel.<ref name=Entrevista>[http://www.eluniverso.com/2010/05/05/1/1378/delfin-quishpe-el-grito-me-identifica.html] "Delfín Quishpe: ‘El grito me identifica’", 05 de mayo del 2010, El Universo.</ref>
==The video==
The opening shot is of video Delfin Quishpe sitting in a living room watching television. People on television speak of war, fear, and the dangers of living in Israel, despite the obvious fact that they are not Israeli. Delfin rises to his feet and shouts "This cannot be," spreading his arms high and wide. The video segues to an introduction of each of the singers. The song then continues as a lovesong to Israel and Israelis.<ref name=Entrevista/> Gastón Cleiman, a [[Buenos Aires]] advertising man who wrote the song’s lyrics describes it as, "a song against prejudice.”<ref name=Carmon/> The score is by [[Gaby Kerpel]] and Daniel Mart.n<ref name=Carmon/> [[Picky Talarico]] directed.<ref name=Carmon/>
==Production==
The tracks were recorded separately. Wendy and Bustos were recorded in Lima, while Delfin was recorded in Ecuador. The music was mixed and the video produced in [[Buenos Aires]] by Gaby Kerpel.<ref name=Tiempo/> The three performers were not acquainted and did not meet during the production of the video.<ref name=Entrevista/>
==Cultural impact==
The video was intended by its creators to be taken as a genuinely naive work, a kind of online [[outsider art]].<ref name=Carmon/> It was taken for such by [[Alma Guillermoprieto]] who gushed over it in the ultra-sophisticated [[New York Review of Books]], calling Latin America "the last great reservoir of innocent art," and continuing:
''"Their self-confidence and optimism we can only envy, and yet they have lives we can barely imagine (how much did the rural violence provoked by Peru’s Shining Path guerrillas influence Wendy’s parents’ decision to migrate to the capital?); they make choices that to us seem inscrutable (what is that monkey doing behind the rowboat?). But millions of people admire these singers. What the video shows us is the chaotic transformation of a culture that has always had an infinite and joyful capacity for self-invention. This is not outsider but insider art of the deepest sort, forged in a hot-hot crucible, and it is we who stand on the outside, peering wistfully at the screen."''<ref name=Guillermoprieto>[http://www.nybooks.com/blogs/nyrblog/2010/jun/09/what-monkey-doing-behind-rowboat/] "What is that Monkey Doing Behind the Rowboat? Alma Guillermoprieto, June 9, 2010, New York Review of Books.</ref>
The video’s great success has brought new opportunities for the three performers. A party promoter brought ''La Tigresa'' to [[Buenos Aires]], where diners in an upscale restaurant greeter her by breaking into the chorus of “En Tus Tierras Bailaré.”<ref name=Carmon/> She was and hailed as a gay icon and stopped in the street by fans wanting photos. There is talk of a world tour, ending in Israel.<ref name=Carmon/>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:En tus Tierras Bailare}} [[Category:Viral videos]] [[Category:Andean music]] [[Category:Peruvian music]] [[Category:Internet memes]] [[Category:2010 works]] [[Category:Songs about Israel]] [[Category:2010 songs]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox holiday |holiday_name = ''Fête des lumières'' |type = historical |longtype = |image = Fête des Lumières - Lyon (2008).JPG |caption = Lyon during the 2008 Festival of Lights, seen from Fourvière hill. |observedby = [[Lyon]], [[France]] |begins = |ends = |date = lik December 31th |date2017 = 7–10 December 2017<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fetedeslumieres.lyon.fr/en/page/dates-and-opening-hours|title=Dates and opening hours at fetedeslumieres.lyon.fr}}</ref> |celebrations = |duration = 4 days |frequency = annual |observances = Candles at windows, light shows in public and historic buildings |relatedto = }}
The '''Festival of Lights''' ({{lang-fr|Fête des lumières}}) in [[Lyon]], [[France]] expresses gratitude toward [[Mary, mother of Jesus]] around December 8th of each year.<ref name="Festival of Lights History" /> This uniquely Lyonnaise tradition dictates that every house place candles along the outsides of all the windows to produce a spectacular effect throughout the streets. The festival includes other activities based on light and usually lasts four days, with the peak of activity occurring on the 8th. The two main focal points of activity are typically the [[Basilica of Fourvière]] which is lit up in different colours, and the [[Place des Terreaux]], which hosts a different light show each year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fetedeslumieres.lyon.fr/en/edition/2010-program|title=2010-program at fetedeslumieres.lyon.fr}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fetedeslumieres.lyon.fr/en/edition/2011-program|title=2011-program at fetedeslumieres.lyon.fr}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fetedeslumieres.lyon.fr/en/edition/2012-program|title=2012-program at fetedeslumieres.lyon.fr}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fetedeslumieres.lyon.fr/en/edition/2013-program|title=2013-program at fetedeslumieres.lyon.fr}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fetedeslumieres.lyon.fr/en/edition/2014-festival|title=2014-festival at fetedeslumieres.lyon.fr}}</ref>
== History ==
=== Spared from plague === The origins of the festival date to 1643 when Lyon was struck by [[Bubonic plague|plague]]. On September 8, 1643 the municipal councillors (''échevins'') promised to pay tribute to Mary if the town was spared. Ever since, a solemn procession makes its way to the Basilica of Fourvière on 8 December (the feast of the [[Immaculate Conception]]) to light candles and give offerings in the name of Mary. In part, the event thus commemorates the day Lyon was consecrated to the Virgin Mary.<ref>[http://www.histoire-pour-tous.fr/tourisme/101-france-sud-est/4995-la-fete-des-lumieres-lyon.html History of Lyon's 'fete des lumieres', at histoire-pour-tous.fr]</ref>
=== Inauguration of a statue === In 1852, it became a popular festival when a statue of the Virgin Mary was erected next to the Basilica, overlooking the city.<ref name="Festival of Lights History" /> Now a focal point of the festival, the statue was created by the renowned sculptor [[Joseph-Hugues Fabisch]] and was sponsored by several notable Lyonnais Catholics. It was then accepted by Maurice Cardinal de Bonald in 1850. The inauguration of the statue was due to take place on September 8, 1852, the day of celebration of the [[Nativity of Mary|Nativity of the Virgin]]<!-- et date anniversaire du vœu des échevins de 1643 -->. However, the flooding of the [[Saône River|Saône]] prevented the statue from being ready. The archbishop, with the agreement of a committee of lay people, therefore chose to move the date back to the 8 December.<ref name="Festival of Lights History">[http://www.fetedeslumieres.lyon.fr/en/page/history Festival of Lights History at fetedeslumieres.lyon.fr]</ref>
By 1852 in Lyon, December 8 had already been a celebration for the Immaculate Conception of the Virgin.<ref name="Festival of Lights History" /> Leading up to the inauguration, everything was in place for the festivities: The statue was lit up with flares, fireworks were readied for launching from the top of Fourvière Hill and marching bands were set to play in the streets. The prominent Catholics of the time suggested lighting up the façades of their homes as was traditionally done for major events such as royal processions and military victories.
However, on the morning of the big day, a storm struck Lyon.<ref name="Festival of Lights History" /> The master of ceremonies hastily decided to cancel everything and to push back the celebrations once more to the following Sunday. In the end the skies cleared and the people of Lyon, who had been eagerly anticipating the event, spontaneously lit up their windows, descended into the streets<ref name="Festival of Lights History" /> and lit flares to illuminate the new statue and the Chapel of Notre-Dame-de-Fourvière, later superseded by the Basilica. The people sang songs and cried "''Vive Marie!''" until late in the night. This celebration was then repeated from year to year.<ref name="Festival of Lights History" />
== Today == [[File:Lumignons_fete_des_Lumieres_Lyon_8-12-2013.jpg|thumbnail|Candle lights on a windowsill on December 8.]] Thus, tradition now dictates that every family in Lyon keep, along with its Christmas decorations, a collection of stained or clear glass in which candles are burnt on windowsills on 8 December. These stout, fluted candles can be found in shops towards the end of November.<ref>[http://www.fetedeslumieres.lyon.fr/fr/page/les-lumignons-du-coeur les-lumignons-du-Coeur ''(Candles of the Heart)'' at fetedeslumieres.lyon.fr]</ref>
Nowadays, the city council puts on professionally run performances. The people of Lyon's participation remains strong as evidenced by numerous façades lit up in the traditional way and by the throngs of people wandering the streets on 8 December.<ref>[https://www.tripadvisor.fr/LocationPhotoDirectLink-g187265-d195594-i71760840-Cathedral_Saint_Jean_Baptiste-Lyon_Rhone_Rhone_Alpes.html Photograph of Cathedral_Saint_Jean_Baptiste-Lyon during fete des lumieres at tripadvisor.fr]</ref>
Historians and sociologists{{who?|date=December 2012}} note the rather misinformed notions that the people of Lyon have concerning the celebration's origins: confusion over the thanks given to Mary, as well as the dates involved, leads people to think the celebration commemorates the establishment of the Basilica of [[Notre-Dame de Fourvière]] or a wish granted after a plague supposedly struck in the 19th century.
Nowadays, the festival draws 3 to 4 million people each year.<ref name=":0" /><ref name="Festival of Lights History" />
== Changes in 2015 and 2016 == In 2015, the festival was scaled back,<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2015/nov/20/lyon-cancels-fete-des-lumieres-in-wake-of-paris-attacks Guardian article, November 2015: 'Lyon cancels fete des lumieres in wake of paris attacks' at theguardian.com]</ref> owing to the nationwide state of emergency banning large assemblies in the wake of the [[November 2015 Paris attacks|November 13 attacks]] in Paris.<ref>[http://www.frenchmoments.eu/the-festival-of-lights-in-lyon-la-fete-des-lumieres-de-lyon/ the festival of lights in lyon 2015 postponed until 2016 at frenchmoments.eu]</ref> The festival was limited to the traditional lumignon candles and an installation which paid tribute to the victims of the terrorist attacks, whose first names were displayed over the buildings of the quays.<ref>[http://www.fetedeslumieres.lyon.fr/en/page/tribute-victims-terrorist-attacks-paris tribute to victims of terrorist attacks in Paris at fetedeslumieres.lyon.fr]</ref>
Because of the continuing risk of attacks, the 2016 edition of the festival took place in a smaller area than usual and will lasted for three days instead of four.<ref>[http://www.fetedeslumieres.lyon.fr/en/news/new-combined-security-system A new combined security system at fetedeslumieres.lyon.fr]</ref> Security inspections were conducted at entrances to the event and additional security forces were provided by the [[Minister of Interior (France)|Minister of the Interior]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/dec/09/lyons-fete-des-lumieres-returns-for-2016-amid-tight-security|title=Lyon's Fête des Lumières returns for 2016 amid tight security|last=Sherwood|first=Harriet|date=9 December 2016|website=The Guardian|archive-url=https://archive.fo/Z1rgd|archive-date=14 November 2018|dead-url=|access-date=14 November 2018}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
== Notes == * ''This article incorporates text translated from [[:fr:Fête des lumières (Lyon)|the corresponding French Wikipedia article]] as of 8 June 2006.''
== See also == * [[Lumiere festival]]
== External links == {{Commons category|Fête des lumières}} * [http://www.fetedeslumieres.lyon.fr/ Official Festival Website] * [https://www.nrc.nl/nieuws/2014/12/06/het-zestiende-lichtfestival-van-lyon Het zestiende Lichtfestival van Lyon ''(The sixteenth Light Festival at Lyon)'' - NRC.nl]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Fete des lumieres}} [[Category:Entertainment in Lyon]] [[Category:Christianity in Lyon]] [[Category:Festivals in France]] [[Category:December events]] [[Category:Culture in Lyon]] [[Category:Winter events in France]] [[Category:Festival of Lights]]

{{More footnotes|date=November 2010}} [[File:Map of Gambling in Russia.svg|thumb|300px|Gambling subjects of Russia:
[[Kaliningrad Oblast]],
[[Azov-City]] ([[Krasnodar Krai]], Rostov Oblast part was excluded from list),
[[Altai Krai]],
[[Primorsky Krai]]]] '''[[Gambling]] in [[Russia]]''' is legal in only four regional subject areas, and in 2009 was made illegal in all other areas of Russia.{{citation needed|date=June 2011}} In 2009, gambling was banned almost everywhere in Russia. The only exceptions are four specially arranged zones in the Altai, Krasnodar, Kaliningrad, and Primorsky regions. ==Public Policy Economics Perspective== Gambling has been a major policy problem for the Russian government since the early 21st century. The problem was the rapidly increasing number of [[slot machine]]s and gambling houses, including [[casino]]s, spreading all over the country. This caused a little concern for the government. According to city officials, after the year 2002 there were 58 casinos, 2,000 gaming rooms and approximately 70,000 slot machines in Moscow.{{cite web|url=http://www.casinoman.net/gambling-news/article/gambling-industry-flourishes-in-russia.4215.asp#|title=Gambling Industry Flourishes in Russia|author=|date=|website=casinoman.net}} It became a greater problem for the government because the [[Demographics of Russia|younger population]] was widely exposed to the obtrusive advertising of gambling houses. Teenagers missed school to crowd around slot machines hoping to win some money. This behavior affected the society’s welfare in a way that was external to the market, thus, giving rise to a negative externality. Experts from the Russian Association of Gambling Business Development claimed that approximately half a million people on a regular basis indulged in gambling in the capital city of Moscow. At the same time, city psychiatrists, who met with people addicted to excessive gambling, provided quite different information arguing that the number was much higher. “The head of the extra-hospital aid in the National Narcological Scientific Center Taras Dudko says that the number of people regularly going to Moscow casinos, bookmaking offices and gambling houses is over 1.5 million people”.{{cite web|url=http://english.pravda.ru/history/08-10-2003/3863-gambling-0/|title=Russian Roulette: Gambling in Russia|first=Michael|last=Simpson|date=8 October 2003|website=pravda.ru}} According to marketing research by Bookmaker-Ratings, in Russia from May 2016 till May 2017 services of illegal offshore bookmakers were used by 1 million 410 thousand players, services of legal Russian bookmakers – by 820 thousand players. {{Cite web|url=https://bookmaker-ratings.ru/wp-content/uploads/2018/01/betting-report-2017-en.pdf|title=Russian bookmaking industry: current state and growth perspectives. May 2017|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}Additionally, money laundering was another concern of every city government that failed to collect estimated tax revenue from gambling businesses, that kept the profits and did not share them with the city by avoiding tax payment. These were the major rationales for the government to get involved and implement a policy on gambling restriction. One of the policy solutions to solve the gambling problem in Russia was proposed in the form of limiting the number of gambling establishments throughout the country. Additionally, the Moscow officials proposed to bar slot machine parlors within 500 yards of a residential area, which would force operators out of all urban areas in the country in order to protect the young generation from being tempted to lose money using slot machines.Федеральный закон Российской Федерации от 29 декабря 2006 г. N 244-ФЗ О государственном регулировании деятельности по организации и проведению азартных игр и о внесении изменений в некоторые законодательные акты Российской Федерации [http://www.rg.ru/2006/12/31/azart-dok.html] The major policy problem about excessive gambling in the Russian society and their people’s continuous discontent with the spread of gambling houses all over the country finally led to the implementation of federal policy. Russia closed down its casinos overnight as gambling was banned nationwide. Thus since July 1, 2009, according to the Federal Law № 244 “On state regulation of organization and management of gambling”, the gambling business in Russia has been allowed only in four designated zones. The ban was to protect the health of society, and was expected to put an end to the era which witnessed an eruption of gambling fueled by a lawless business culture, which caused great costs to the society. Despite the ban, gambling continues working, pretending to be Internet cafes, lottery clubs, nightclubs. ==History== {{Expand section|date=December 2009}} At the end of 1927, the [[People’s Commissar of the Interior]] presented a report devoted to gambling and the gaming business existing at that time to the RSFSR SPC. The main idea voiced through the report was that its incompatibility of an idle, bourgeois pastime with the true spirit of the working proletariat. And, regardless of the rather modest figures in the gaming sector (for example, only 4 small gaming houses operated in [[Leningrad]] at that time), the key prohibitive provisions in the report were approved. All this led to a ban on the opening of gambling houses in worker districts, it was followed by a ban on gambling in the entire districts, and later, on May 8, 1928, by the resolution of the USSR SPC, all Soviet Republics were instructed, the reasons not being explained, "to take measures on the immediate closure of any facilities for card games, roulette, lotto and other kinds of gambling". The closure of gaming houses and the gambling ban were pushed by the penal policy course shaped by the [[Soviet state]], providing for overall reinforcement of criminal sanctions in the country and the modification of the state's penitentiary policy upon the whole. Later, lotteries were also restricted. On June 6, 1928, the Workers-Peasants’ Government of the RSFSR issues the resolution, "On Banning the Draw of Liquors in Lotteries". First, on January 1, 1930, the USSR SPC issues the resolution "On the Procedure of Issuing Permits for Lottery Arrangement", and then, on August 31, 1932, another USSR SPC Resolution #1336 was announced, "On the Regulation of the Lottery Business". The first slot machines which appeared in the country quite lawfully, were installed only in 1988 in hotels which were part of the USSR [[State Committee of Foreign Tourism]] (Goscomintourist). Within the system, the All-Russian Business External Trade Union (VHVO) "Intourservice" is set up, developing new kinds of additional services for foreign tourists, payable in free convertible currency. And private businesses have no access to gambling operations. Despite an eagerness to deal with slot machine installation and operation, the Soviete authorities allowed it only within its state structures, only as an experiment. To be on the safe side, there was a legal reminder that the business still cannot be entered. On December 29, 1988, the [[Council of Ministers (Soviet Union)|Council of Ministers of the USSR]] issued another resolution, this time "On the Regulation of Certain Activities of Cooperatives According to the Law on Cooperation in the USSR", which, in particular, stressed that cooperatives are not entitled to perform gambling operations. On August 23, 1989, the Soviet government lifted its ban on gambling and opened the first gambling house in Moscow and later, the first casino was opened in the capital city’s Savoy Hotel. Poker in Russia was very popular during the collapse of the USSR, when people started being interested in Western culture and values. In the Soviet Union it was possible to play poker only in cellar clubs or the casino. In addition, players often gathered in private flats. By the end of the 90s it was the first attempt to hold poker tournaments, but it did not get the widespread popularity at the time. ==Taxation== In 2004, the Law #142-FZ “On Gambling Tax” being in effect for a sixth year, Chapter 29 “Gambling Tax” of the Russian Federation’s Tax Code came into effect. A new and the most complicated stage in the area of gambling taxation began. As of January 1, 2004, gambling tax became regional and its receipts are transferred to the budgets of the Federation’s constituent entities. As of 2004, each region was entitled to independently determine the gambling tax rate within the limits provided for by the Law #142-FZ “On Gambling Tax”. The taxation rate for [[slot machines]] with cash winnings was 1,500 to 7,500 roubles and for gaming tables, totalisator cash desks and [[bookmaker]] cash desks – 25,000 to 125,000 roubles. Any previous privileges with regard to the gambling tax were cancelled. ==Legality== {{Expand section|date=October 2017}} The state regulation of activities involved in gambling organisation and arrangement was performed by the government, by the federal executive agency authorised by the government to perform functions on standard and legal regulation in the area of gambling organisation, by other federal executive authorities within their competence and by the governmental bodies of the Russian Federation’s constituent entities, authorised to perform the functions of gaming zone management. Gambling may be arranged solely by legal entities registered according to the set procedure within the Russian Federation. Gambling cannot be arranged by legal entities, the founders (participants) of which include the Russian Federation, the Russian Federation’s constituent entities or local government authorities. The law contemplates that four gaming zones will be created within the Russian Federation; meanwhile no more than one gaming zone may be created within one and the same constituent entity. If Legal Requlation of Gambling in Former USSR Countries and Foreign States the created gaming zone belongs to several regions, no other gaming zones may be created within their territories. Gaming zones are to be set up within the Altay, Primorie and Kaliningrad regions and on the border between the Krasnodar region and Rostov region.[http://en.rian.ru/russia/20100130/157720203.html First casino to open in Russian gambling zone] The procedure of gaming zone creation and liquidation, their names, borders and other characteristics, will be determined by the government upon an agreement with the government bodies in constituent entities. The existence of gaming zones has no time limits. A decision on the liquidation of a gaming zone by the government may not be made until ten years after it was created. A ruling on the creation of a gaming zone may set requirements for certain types of gambling facilities, as well as other restrictions. Gambling facilities, except bookmakers’ offices and totalisators, may be opened only within the gaming zones according to the procedure set out by the law. Furthermore, the boundaries of the gaming zones should have been outlined by July 1, 2007, whereas they cannot be created on land in populated localities. The names of the territories are "Siberian Coin" (Altay),{{cite web|url=http://www.russia-ic.com/business_law/in_depth/1306/|title=Gambling in Russia|author=|date=|website=russia-ic.com}} "Yantarnaya" (Kaliningrad region), "Azov-city" (Rostov region) and "Primorie" (Primorie region). The gambling operator should submit the data needed for exercising control of compliance with the legislative requirements. The net assets of the gambling operator, throughout the entire period of their activities, cannot be less than: 600,000,000 roubles (for operators of casinos and slot halls) and 100,000,000 roubles (for operators of bookmakers’ offices and totalisators). The procedure for the calculation of the value of the gambling operator’s net assets will be set by the Ministry of Finance, while the Government may establish additional requirements for gambling operators. The gambling operator shall secure the personal safety of gamblers, other visitors to gambling facilities and their employees during their stay in the gambling facility. People under 18 cannot be the gambling operator’s employees or visit a gambling facility. Gambling facilities may be located only in buildings which are capital construction projects. Gambling facilities cannot be located in residential fund properties, uncompleted constructions, temporary structures, kiosks, open shelters and other similar premises; in buildings and constructions where children’s, educational, healthcare and sanatorium institutions are located; in buildings and constructions including bus stations, railway stations, river stations, river ports, airports, at stations and stops for any public transport(common carriers) for urban and suburban services, etc., as well as on plots of land where the above-mentioned facilities are situated. Bookmakers’ offices and totalisators, apart from those opened within gaming zones, may be opened solely based on licences, the procedure of issuing which will be determined by the government The customer service area for gamblers in casinos cannot be less than 800 square metres. The customer service area in a casino shall feature at least ten gaming tables. Should slot machines be installed in the casino customer service area, the area of the slot machine zone cannot be less than 100 square metres and the zone shall feature at least 50 slot machines. The technically implied average winnings (payback) from a slot machine cannot be less than 90 percent The law came into effect as of January 1, 2007. The gambling facilities which comply with the above-mentioned requirements may continue their operations till June 30, 2009, without obtaining permits for activities on gambling organisation and arrangement in gaming zones. Any gambling facilities that fail to comply with the requirements set out by the law shall be closed by July 1, 2007. Gambling operations using information and telecommunication networks, including the Internet, and communication means, including mobile communications, are prohibited. Gaming business licensing was also changed. In fact, there remained only one activity to be licensed – the organisation and arrangement of gambling in bookmakers’ offices and totalisators. In legal terms, gambling operations in casinos and slot halls will exist only on a pro forma basis as of July 1, 2007 and as of July 1, 2009, licensing will be completely substituted with a system of permits and shift to a regional level from a federal one.Federal law "On state regulation of organization and management of gambling..." The latest edition of the law on gambling business falls on March 28, 2017. This Act regulates the legal framework of state control over the activities of institutions that organize gambling. The Act introduces restrictions on the exercise of this activity in order to protect citizens' morals and the legitimate interests of the population.{{cite web|url=https://rg.ru/2017/03/31/sport-dok.html|title=Федеральный закон от 28 марта 2017 г. N 44-ФЗ "О внесении изменений в отдельные законодательные акты Российской Федерации в части формирования механизмов увеличения доходов субъектов детско-юношеского спорта и субъектов профессионального спорта"|author=|date=|website=Российская газета}} ==See also== *[[The Gambler (novel)|''The Gambler'' (novel)]], written in 1867 and set in Russia *[[Russian roulette]], often attributed to having started in Russia *[[Problem gambling]] *[[Fyodor Dostoyevsky]], a Russian who is considered to be one of Europe's major novelists, became addicted to gambling. ==Notes== {{Reflist}} ==References== *[http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-russia-casinos1-2009jul01,0,753321.story Los Angeles Times: Irked gamblers cash in their chips as Russia follows through on casino ban] *[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/06/25/AR2005062501035.html Washington Post: Gambling Industry Explodes In Russia] *Legal regulation of gambling in former USSR countries, [[Evgeny Kovtun]]. {{ISBN|978-5-903391-12-7}} {{Gambling by country}} {{Economy of Russia}} {{Russia topics}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gambling In Russia}} [[Category:Gambling in Russia]] [[Category:Russian society]] [[Category:Economy of Russia]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox Website |name=GameZombie |logo=GameZombie Logo.png |logo_size=240px |screenshot= |url=http://www.gamezombie.tv/ |type=Game Media Studio |author= Spencer Striker |launch date=2007 |current status=Active |revenue= }}
'''GameZombie TV''' is a [[web series]] that produces original video game shows. GameZombie was the recipient of a [[Webby Award|Webby]] Honoree Award for Online Video in 2008 <ref>[http://www.webbyawards.com/webbys/current_honorees.php?media_id=97&category_id=108&season=12 Webby Honorees, 2008]</ref> and 2009,<ref>[http://www.webbyawards.com/webbys/current_honorees.php?media_id=97&category_id=108&season=13 Webby Honorees, 2009]</ref> a Davey Award, a Webby Award, and a People's Voice Webby Award in 2010, and nominated a finalist for Best Web Video at the 4th Annual [[Mashable#Mashable Awards|Mashable Awards]].<ref>[http://www.daveyawards.com/winners/list/?l=G&event=6&category=&award=S&form=2 Davey Silver Winners, 2010]</ref><ref>[http://www.webbyawards.com/webbys/current.php?media_id=97&season=14/ Webby Winners, 2010]</ref><ref>[http://host.madison.com/wsj/news/local/education/university/article_d8228772-75b4-11df-a387-001cc4c002e0.html UW-Whitewater students head to New York to accept Webby Awards], Wisconsin State Journal, Patricia Simms, June 11, 2010</ref><ref>[http://mashable.com/2010/12/01/mashable-awards-announcing-the-full-list-of-finalists/ Mashable Awards: Announcing The Full List of Finalists] Mashable, December 01, 2010, by Vadim Lavrusik</ref> The student-run game media studio, based out of the [[University of Wisconsin at Whitewater]] and [[Indiana University at Bloomington]], has amassed one of the most complete [[video game developer]] interview series on the web.<ref>[http://newsinfo.iu.edu/news/page/normal/8045.html Student-produced GameZombie.tv Web site named a Webby Honoree], IU News Room, April 23, 2008</ref><ref>[http://newsinfo.iu.edu/news/page/normal/10796.html Student-produced GameZombie.tv is a Webby Honoree for second straight year], IU News Room, May 14, 2009</ref> GameZombie has created upwards of 450 videos for online distribution.<ref>[http://phobos.apple.com/WebObjects/MZStore.woa/wa/viewPodcast?i=25619465&id=163350156 WTIU Weekly Special (5/1/08)]</ref> GameZombie's videos have amassed over 8,000,000 unique, aggregate views since the company's first video went online in March 2007.<ref>[http://www.bebo.com/c/video?FlashBoxId=8161486391&# ButtonMashers Season 1 -Episode 2 (4.2 million displays on Bebo)]</ref><ref>[http://www.tubemogul.com/profile/GameZombie/ Tubemogul Stats (over 3.8 million views)]</ref> GameZombie TV's [[Constructivism (learning theory)|constructivist]], [[project-based learning]] environment is a finalist for the [[John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation|MacArthur Foundation]]'s 4th Annual [[HASTAC#Digital Media and Learning Competition|Digital Media and Learning Competition]] <ref>[http://royalpurplenews.com/?p=5515 GameZombie.tv nominated for grant, introduces ‘Couch’] Royal Purple, Ben Holzhueter, Feb 1, 2012</ref><ref>[http://www.uww.edu/news/archive/2011-12-gamezombie-grant Student web series nominated for $200,000 grant] UWW University News, Jeff Angileri, December 15, 2011</ref><ref>[http://www.dmlcompetition.net/media/4/stage-one-content-winners.pdf Digital Media and Learning Competition Press Release: Stage One Winners Announced] December 5, 2011</ref><ref>[http://www.dmlcompetition.net/Competition/4/winning-projects.php?group=dmlc-4b Badges for Lifelong Learning Competition Stage One Learning Content Winners and Collaborators]</ref>
== History == '''GameZombie''' was started by Spencer Striker in March 2007 while he was a graduate student in [[Indiana University|Indiana University’s]] Masters in Immersive Mediated Environments program.<ref>[http://www.idsnews.com/news/story.aspx?id=63763&comview=1 Video gaming Web site offers education, jobs], Indiana Daily Student, October 20, 2008</ref><ref>[http://www.idsnews.com/news/story.aspx?id=68497 GameZombie.tv site to earn Webby Award], Indiana Daily Student, June 7, 2009</ref><ref>[http://web.mac.com/spencerstriker/spencerstriker/Press_files/OurTown_SS_overview.jpg Bloom Magazine Presents Our Town 2010/2011, (August 2011)], featuring Spencer Striker by Jeremy Shere, p. 73</ref> When based in [[Bloomington, Indiana]], GameZombie became the city's largest employer of student interns.<ref>[http://www.heraldtimesonline.com/stories/2008/05/03/news.qp-5411427.sto ‘Zombie’ gamers among the caps and gowns], Herald Times, May 3, 2008</ref><ref>[http://www.heraldtimesonline.com/stories/2009/06/11/scene.nw-674030.sto GameZombie.tv crew named Webby honoree a 2nd time], Herald Times, June 11, 2009</ref> Around 50 to 60 students between the two universities take GameZombie for academic credit each semester in order to gain experience in a multimedia studio.<ref>[http://www.jsonline.com/features/technology/91923699.html GameZombie reviews come with tech lesson], Milwaukee Journal Sentinel, Stanley A. Miller II, April 24, 2010</ref><ref>[http://walworthcountytoday.com/news/2010/jan/26/web-site-hit-gamers-real-life-eduction-students/ Web site a hit with gamers, real-life education for students], Walworth County Today, Lisa M. Schmelz, January 26, 2010</ref>
== Original Video Series ==
===Developer Interview Series=== GameZombie’s video game developer interview series includes over 200 video interviews with notable game developers,<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL139E4E7151C9B990 Game Developers - Playlist]</ref> video game personalities,<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLF3889730A47D089C Gaming Personalities - Playlist]</ref> and makers of gaming peripherals.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLD4887EE0F21335DF Gaming Peripherals - Playlist]</ref>
GameZombie's annual gaming conference coverage includes the [[Electronic Entertainment Expo]], the [[Game Developers Conference]], the [[Penny Arcade Expo]], [[Gen Con]], [[San Diego Comic-Con International|Comic-Con]], and the [[World Series of Video Games]].<ref>[http://www.destructoid.com/gamezombie-tv-rolling-with-the-last-guys-on-the-planet-99062.phtml GameZombie.tv: Rolling with the last guys on the planet], Destructoid, August 8, 2008</ref><ref>[http://newteevee.com/2008/08/31/zombies-game-news-15m-views/ Zombies + Game News = 1.5M Views], NewTeeVee, August 31, 2008</ref> Series interviews include: [[Peter Molyneux]] of 'Fable 2,' [[Ed Boon]] of 'MK vs DC,' [[Todd Howard (video game designer)|Todd Howard]] of 'Fallout 3,' [[Ben Mattes]] of 'Prince of Persia,' [[Cliff Bleszinski]] of 'Gears of War 2,' [[Eric Holmes (videogame designer)|Eric Holmes]] of 'Prototype,' [[Clint Hocking]] of 'Far Cry 2,' [[Evan Wells]] of 'Uncharted 2,' [[Neill Glancy]] of 'Stranglehold,' [[Chuck Beaver]] of 'Dead Space,' [[Fatal1ty]] (pro gamer), [[The Angry Video Game Nerd]] (gaming critic), [[Geoff Keighley]] (gaming host), [[Al Alcorn]] (co-creator of Pong), [[Ralph Baer]] ('inventor' of video games), [[Tommy Tallarico]] of 'Video Games Live,' and [[Jane McGonigal]] of 'I Love Bees.'
===ButtonMashers=== ButtonMashers, a live studio production, was shot in a $2.5 million [[HDTV]] studio at Indiana University. <ref>[http://news.tubefilter.tv/2009/02/11/gamezombies-buttonmashers-gets-gamers-all-riled-up/ GameZombie’s 'ButtonMashers’ Gets Gamers All Riled Up], [[Tubefilter]], February 11, 2009</ref> The 14 episodes produced over two seasons featured the collaboration of hundreds of students and accumulated millions of views around the web.<ref>[http://news.tubefilter.tv/2009/07/27/buttonmashers-resets-with-season-2-lands-gaming-sponsor/ ‘ButtonMashers’ Resets With Season 2, Lands Gaming Sponsor], [[Tubefilter]], July 27, 2009</ref>
===Ultimate Challenge=== GameZombie's 'Ultimate Challenge' is a motion graphics based original web series where three college aged gamers get trapped inside a fictional [[NES]] game. Over the course of six episodes the main characters encounter slime monsters, princesses, and boss battles.
==References== {{reflist}}
==Sources== *[http://www.killerstartups.com/Video-Music-Photo/gamezombie-tv-videogame-reviews GameZombie.tv - Videogame Reviews | Visit gamezombie.tv], KillerStartups.com, September 1, 2008 *[http://web.mac.com/spencerstriker/spencerstriker/Press_files/Telecomment.pdf Gamers become Zombies; win Webby Award] Telecomment, Vol. 18, Fall 2008 *[http://web.me.com/spencerstriker/spencerstriker/Press_files/GZ_BloomMag_JuneJuly09_p68.pdf GameZombie has put B-town on the Web-Tech Map] Bloom Mag, June/July 2009, (business/finance, pg 68); Szymanski, Zak *[http://video.i4u.com/index.php?url=gdc/gamezombie.wmv&p=1 I4U News Interview: GameZombie] GDC, March 16, 2007 *[http://journalism.indiana.edu/classwork/bloomingtonsource/arts-entertainment/technologys-role-is-all-games-in-bloomingtons-creative-class/ Technology's role is all games in Bloomington's creative class], the Bloomington Source, May 7, 2009; Casady, Danny *[http://www.insideindianabusiness.com/newsitem.asp?ID=35601 IU Students Up For a Webby Award], Inside Indiana Business, May 14, 2009 *[http://www.uww.edu/news/archive/2009-10-gamezombie-tv GameZombie TV continues development at UW-Whitewater], Marketing & Media Relations, University of Wisconsin at Whitewater, October 15, 2009 *[http://gazettextra.com/news/2009/oct/30/web-series-project-offers-real-life-experience-uw-/ Web series project offers real-life experience to UW-W students], GazetteXtra.com, Kayla Bunge, October 30, 2009 *[http://media.www.royalpurplenews.com/media/storage/paper1225/news/2009/11/11/Spotlight/New-Class.Allows.Students.To.Work.In.Video.Game.Industry-3828682.shtml New class allows students to work in video game industry], Royal Purple, Matt Gardner, November 11, 2009 *[http://media.www.royalpurplenews.com/media/storage/paper1225/news/2009/12/09/News/UwWhitewater.Rolls.Dice.On.New.Gaming.Major-3848043.shtml UW-Whitewater rolls dice on new gaming major], Royal Purple, Rob Gauler, December 9, 2009 *[http://www.uww.edu/news/archive/2010-04-gamezombie-tv-votes Votes needed to win people's voice award], Marketing & Media Relations, University of Wisconsin at Whitewater, April 16, 2010 *[http://www.biztimes.com/bubbler/2010/4/22/uw-w-student-group-could-win-webby-award UW-W student group could win Webby Award], BizTimes.com, April 22, 2010 *[http://newsinfo.iu.edu/news/page/normal/14191.html IU Office of Scholarships, GameZombie.tv honored with Webby Awards], IU News Room, Sarah Booher, April 19, 2010 *[http://www.uww.edu/news/archive/2010-05-gamezombie-tv-webby-awards GameZombie TV sweeps Webby Awards in Student category], Marketing & Media Relations, University of Wisconsin at Whitewater, May 5, 2010 *[http://www.uww.edu/news/archive/2010-12-gamezombie-tv Student-run GameZombie TV named best Web video finalist], Marketing & Media Relations, University of Wisconsin at Whitewater, December 9, 2010 *[http://royalpurplenews.com/?p=3233 GameZombie.tv continues expanding], Royal Purple, Ben Holzhueter, September 21, 2011 *[http://videogamewriters.com/picking-the-brains-of-game-zombie-tv-9618/ Picking the Brains of GameZombie TV], Video Game Writers, Daniel Wise, May 11, 2011

revision.text:
{{Infobox book | name = Good Masters! Sweet Ladies! Voices from a Medieval Village | title_orig = | translator = | image = Good Masters Sweet Ladies.jpg | image_size = 200px | caption = | author = [[Laura Amy Schlitz]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = | language = English | series = | subject = | genre = | published = July 24, 2007 [[Candlewick Press]] | awards = [[Newbery Medal]] | media_type = Print ([[Hardcover]], [[paperback]]) | pages = 96 | isbn = 0-7636-1578-1 | oclc = 53178700 | dewey = 812.6 | congress = PS3619.C43 C55 2007 | preceded_by = | followed_by = }}
'''''Good Masters! Sweet Ladies! Voices from a Medieval Village''''' is a 2007 [[children's literature|children's book]] written by [[Laura Amy Schlitz]]. The book was awarded the 2008 [[Newbery Medal]] for excellence in children's literature.<ref name="Thompson">Thompson, Bob. "Children's Book Award Winners Break The Mold." ''[[The Washington Post]]'', 2008-01-15, p. C1.</ref>
== Overview ==
Instead of the typical [[narrative]] structure, the book is constructed of a series of [[monologues]], each spoken by a young member of a [[Middle Ages|medieval]] village. Each character has a monologue with the exceptions of Petronella and Jacob, and Mariot and Maud, who have dialogues. The book was originally written to be performed by fifth-grade students at the [[Park School of Baltimore]], where Schlitz is a librarian. It contains nineteen monologues and two dialogues, with the characters ranging from a runaway boy to the lord's daughter.<ref name="Thompson"/>
== Monologues/Dialogues (in order of appearance) == * Hugo, the Lord's nephew * Taggot, the blacksmith's daughter * Will, the plowboy * Alice, the shepherdess * Thomas, the doctor's son * Constance, the pilgrim * Mogg, the villein's daughter * Otho, the miller's son * Jack, the half-wit * Simon, the knight's son * Edgar, the falconer's son * Isobel, the Lord's daughter * Barbary, the mud slinger * Jacob Ben Salomon, the moneylender's son and Petronella, the merchant's daughter * Lowdy, the varlet's child * Pask, the runaway * Piers, the glassblower's apprentice * Mariot and Maud, the glassblower's daughters * Nelly, the sniggler * Drogo, the tanner's apprentice * Giles, the beggar <ref>{{Cite web|title = Library of Congress Catalog that contains the complete list of contents|url = http://lccn.loc.gov/2003065256|website = Library of Congress|accessdate = 2015-04-20}}</ref>
== Critical reception ==
According to ''[[Kirkus Reviews]]'', "Schlitz takes the breath away with unabashed excellence in every direction."<ref>{{cite journal|url=https://www.kirkusreviews.com/book-reviews/laura-amy-schlitz/good-masters-sweet-ladies/|journal=[[Kirkus Reviews]]|title=GOOD MASTERS! SWEET LADIES! by Laura Amy Schlitz, Robert Byrd|date=July 15, 2007|accessdate=January 23, 2017}}</ref> Deirdre F. Baker wrote in ''[[The Horn Book Magazine]]'', "Byrd's pristine, elegant pen-and-ink illustrations in opulent colors make the book almost too visually appealing, belying the realistically dirty, stinky conditions described in the text."<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.hbook.com/2013/06/authors-illustrators/reviews-of-books-by-robert-byrd/#_|journal=[[The Horn Book Magazine]]|last=Bircher|first=Katie|title=Reviews of books by Robert Byrd|date=June 6, 2013|accessdate=January 23, 2017}}</ref> John Schwartz, in ''[[The New York Times]]'', called Schlitz a "talented storyteller" and praised the book for its frank depiction of the Middle Ages.<ref name="Schwartz Times review">{{cite news|last=Schwartz|first=John|title=You Are There: 1255|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/12/16/books/review/Schwartz-t.html|accessdate=January 23, 2017|journal=[[The New York Times]]|date=December 16, 2007}}</ref> Nina Lindsay, chair of the Newbery Medal committee, called the monologues "superb" and stated that as a whole, they "create a pageant that transports readers to a different time and place."<ref name="2008 Newbery">{{cite web|title=2008 Newbery Medal and Honor Books|url=http://www.ala.org/ala/mgrps/divs/alsc/awardsgrants/bookmedia/newberymedal/newberyhonors/2008newberymedalhonors.cfm|publisher=American Library Association|accessdate=5 August 2010}}</ref>
In 2008, [[Anita Silvey]], author of ''100 Best Books for Children'', described ''Good Masters! Sweet Ladies!'' in a ''[[School Library Journal]]'' article as one of several recent Newbery winners considered "particularly disappointing" by public librarians. Silvey "criticized the Newbery selections as too difficult for most children."<ref>{{cite journal|first=Anita|last=Silvey|authorlink=Anita Silvey|date=October 1, 2008|accessdate=June 21, 2017|url=http://www.slj.com/2008/10/industry-news/has-the-newbery-lost-its-way/|title=Has the Newbery Lost Its Way?|journal=[[School Library Journal]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/01/27/books/27newb.html?_r=1&8dpc|title='The Graveyard Book' Wins Newbery Medal|first=Motoko|last=Rich|journal=The New York Times|date=January 26, 2009|accessdate=January 23, 2017}}</ref> Writing for ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'', Erica S. Perl responded to this criticism, saying that while her younger self might not have enjoyed the subject matter or archaic language, her "inner drama geek" would have enjoyed the theatrical elements.<ref name="Perl Slate">{{cite web|last=Perl|first=Erica|title=Captain Underpants Doesn't Need a Newbery Medal|url=http://www.slate.com/id/2207160|publisher=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]|accessdate=5 August 2010}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}} {{Portal |Children's literature}}
{{S-start}} {{s-ach|aw}} {{Succession box|title=[[Newbery Medal|Newbery Medal recipient]]|before=''[[The Higher Power of Lucky]]''|after=''[[The Graveyard Book]]''|years=[[2008 in literature|2008]]}} {{S-end}}
[[Category:2007 children's books]] [[Category:American children's books]] [[Category:American historical fiction]] [[Category:Children's fiction books]] [[Category:England in fiction]] [[Category:Monologues]] [[Category:Newbery Medal-winning works]] [[Category:1250s in fiction]]
