revision.text:
{{Infobox video game |title = Gothic 3 |image = Gothic3 EUcover.jpg | alt = European cover art |developer = [[Piranha Bytes]] |publisher = {{vgrelease|EU|[[JoWooD Productions]]|EU|[[Deep Silver]]|AUS|[[Auran]]|NA|[[Aspyr Media]]}} |composer = Kai Rosenkranz <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm2435971/|title=Kai Rosenkranz|website=[[IMDb]]|accessdate=April 16, 2015}}</ref> |series = ''[[Gothic (series)|Gothic]]'' |engine = |released = {{vgrelease|EU|October 13, 2006|AUS|November 14, 2006|NA|November 14, 2006}} |genre = [[Action role-playing game|Action role-playing]] |modes = [[Single-player]] |platforms = [[Microsoft Windows]] }} '''''Gothic 3''''' is a [[fantasy]]-themed [[open world]] [[action role-playing game]] for [[Microsoft Windows]] from the [[Germany|German]] game developer [[Piranha Bytes]].<ref name="gspot_review">{{cite web|url=https://www.gamespot.com/reviews/gothic-3-review/1900-6162673/|title=Gothic 3 Review|last=Park|first=Andrew|date=December 4, 2006|website=[[GameSpot]]|publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]|accessdate=April 19, 2016}}</ref> It is the sequel to ''[[Gothic II]]''. Although widely available in English, the native release of the game is German. The North American release incorporates two [[Patch (software)|patch]]es that appeared after the initial UK edition.
A ''Collector's Edition'' was also released containing bonus collectible material. [[JoWooD Entertainment|JoWooD]] released a standalone expansion, entitled ''[[Gothic 3: Forsaken Gods]]'', in November 2008.
==Gameplay== The player must complete quests and slay wild animals and monsters to earn experience and improve skills. The game is reputation centric allowing the player to side with a faction. While there are six factions in the game, only three are joinable: the Rebels, the Orc mercenaries and the Hashishin. The remaining factions are the Rangers, the Nomads and the people of Nordmar. The player is able to take advantage of missions to allow either side to take over towns. Dialog changes according to in-game actions and behavior. The game places a special focus on the interactivity of the environment. The controls have been altered slightly with a stronger focus on action. Navigation and combat are more mouse-centric, with each mouse button having a different combat action. The Nameless Hero can also now wield dual weapons or use a shield.
==Synopsis==
===Prologue=== The [[Gothic (video game)|first part of Gothic]] tells the story of The Nameless Hero, a man thrust into the events of a penal colony. The colony takes the form of a [[natural landscape]] encased in a large magical shield known as The Barrier, much like an impenetrable dome. Over the course of the story, The Nameless Hero becomes acquainted with several characters, the most notable of which are Diego, Lee, Cor Angar, Lester, Gorn, Lares, Milten, and Xardas. Some of these characters are connected with the various factions of the game, which include the ''Old Camp'', the ''New Camp'' and the ''Swamp Camp''. Also connected with these factions are the water and fire mages, of which Xardas is an outcast. Xardas, a necromancer, plays a central part to the survival and advancement of the character. Ultimately, he galvanizes the character toward the ultimate goal of stopping the summoning of a beast known as ''The Sleeper'', but the entrance was guarded by a camp of orcs. The hero was helped by an orc shaman named Ur-Shak, who made an artifact that would prevent the orcs from attacking him. The Nameless Hero banishes ''The Sleeper'' at the cost of nearly losing his own life.
The [[Gothic II|second part of Gothic]] sees The Nameless Hero resurrected by Xardas into a new setting. Now located outside the city of Khorinis, he is asked by Xardas to investigate a new evil that threatens Khorinis and the surrounding lands. Over the course of the story, The Nameless Hero reconnects with old friends from the first chapter while adjusting to changes in the faction structure. With the penal colony and its barrier a thing of the past, the surrounding lands have been invaded by orcs. Factions now consist of the ''Militia/Paladins'' of Khorinis, the ''Fire Novices/Fire Mages'', and the ''Mercenaries/Dragon Hunters''. Water mages also make a return. Having discovered the source of the evil threatening Khorinis, our hero assembles a crew of trusted friends and sails to a nearby island. There he battles a large undead dragon, completing the central quest of the chapter. The chapter closes with the hero and his allies sailing away from the island.
''Gothic 2'' also has an expansion called ''Night of the Raven''. In the expansion, the Hero faced many new dangers and a new unexplored world. The Water Mages played an important role in the expansion. There was a new faction known as the Ring of Water, who had the same relationship to the Water Mages as the Paladins do to the Fire Mages. The main antagonist was Raven, who was second-in-command to Gomez, leader of the Old Camp, in the first game. Raven wanted to command the armies of Beliar, the evil one of the 3 gods, along with a new powerful weapon known as the Claw of Beliar.
===Plot=== The third part opens with the Nameless Hero and his friends sailing to a new continent overrun with orcs, arriving in Myrtana, the central region of the continent. The hero lost all his belongings from the previous game when his ship is stolen while he's onshore with Milten, Diego, Gorn, and Lester. Presumably this is the source of the orc invasion that was launched on Khorinis during the second chapter. These lands have no physical connection to Khorinis or the ruins of the penal colony. In these mountainous forests the orcs have enslaved the human kingdom with only a few free humans living in the nearly uninhabitable icy northlands of Nordmar and the southern desert of Varant. The hero must decide whether to join the rebellion and stay true to the deposed human king, serve the Orcish usurpers in their quest to topple the last remaining human stronghold, or choose a path that serves his own ends. Throughout the story, he is accompanied by a number of NPCs, some of whom are old friends. While this chapter brings forward friends from the previous title (Xardas, Diego, Milten, Gorn, Lester, Lee, and Vatras) it also introduces two new major characters; King Rhobar the Second (who ultimately was responsible for sending the Nameless Hero to the penal colony in the first game) and Zuben. While the king has a strong past as a bold leader, he now faces a near defeat; his fame is on the decline. Zuben leads the Hashishin that inhabit the southern region of Varant.<ref name="gothic3manual">''Gothic 3'' manual (all versions).</ref>
==Development== ''Gothic 3'' is powered by a custom engine called Genome; it supports [[Pixel Shader|Pixel Shader 3.0]], has a [[Multithreading (computer architecture)|multithreaded]] design and includes dynamic lighting (including [[self-shadowing]]). Character animation uses EMotion FX 2 and physics simulation is provided by [[Ageia]]'s [[PhysX]] [[physics engine]]. It also uses IDV's [[SpeedTree|SpeedTreeRT]] tree and plant software, [[Bink video|Bink Video Technology]] from [[RAD Game Tools]] for the cutscenes, as well as the [[FMOD|FMOD Sound System]] from Firelight Technologies for sound playback.<ref name="gothic3manual"/>
The game was designed for a minimum system requirement of a 2.0 GHz Intel Pentium 4 with 768 MB System [[Random-access memory|RAM]]; recommended video cards include an ATI [[X1600]], Nvidia [[GeForce 6800]] series or better if possible.<ref name="gothic3manual"/>
===Post-release=== After a release with many problems and bugs, a dispute between the publisher and developer led to their separation in 2007.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pluto13.de/docs/PiranhaBytesJoWooD.pdf|title=Piranha Bytes und JoWood gehen getrennte Wege|language=German|website=[[Piranha Bytes]]|date=May 22, 2007}}</ref> The game remained with the last released patch 1.12 in a buggy and unfinished state, and an announced further patch and editor were not finished.{{Citation needed|date=April 2016}}
Therefore, the copyright holding publisher Jowood granted access to the [[source code]] to developers from the game community to allow the fans at least take care of the significant problems and bugs themselves.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://forum.jowood.com/showthread.php?t=144237|title=Das Patch-Projekt|language=German|website=[[JoWooD Entertainment]]|date=June 17, 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100930144752/http://forum.jowood.com/showthread.php?t=144237|archivedate=September 30, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://press.jowood.com/html/News/news_details.php?id=898&title=NEWS&bereich=60|title=Gothic 3 Patch – Release Anfang 2008|language=German|website=JoWooD Entertainment|date=December 20, 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080121112650/http://press.jowood.com/html/News/news_details.php?id=898&title=NEWS&bereich=60|archivedate=January 21, 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.computerbild.de/artikel/cbs-Aktuell-Demos-Patches-Gothic-3-Fan-Patch-1.6-veroeffentlicht-1270192.html|title=Gothic 3: Fan-Patch 1.6 veröffentlicht|last=Schuldt|first=Rainer|date=February 8, 2008|language=German|website=[[Computer Bild]]|accessdate=April 3, 2011}}</ref> In years of voluntary and unpaid work the fan community produced several [[Unofficial patch|community patches]], with an actual iteration version 1.75 released on April 2012. With this 1.5 GB sized patch<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.worldofgothic.de/dl/download_478.htm|title=Gothic 3 Community Patch v1.75|language=German|website=World of Gothic|date=April 25, 2012|accessdate=April 16, 2015}}</ref> significant enhancements and fixes were introduced, so that finally a playable state of the game was achieved.<ref name=g3>{{cite web|url=https://www.golem.de/0903/66059.html|title=Gothic 3 Community Patch soll fast alle Fehler beheben - Mehr als 700 Veränderungen im letzten Community Patch|last=Sebayang|first=Andreas|date=March 23, 2009|language=German|website=Golem.de|accessdate=April 4, 2011}}</ref> Also, a "Community Story Project" still works on fixing inconsistencies in former ''Gothic'' games and on filling story gaps.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pcgameshardware.de/Gothic-3-Spiel-4368/News/Gothic-3-Community-Story-Projekt-691086/|title=Gothic 3 Community Story Projekt - Update: Vergleichsbilder und Youtube-Video|last=Bayer|first=Thilo|date=January 3, 2010|language=German|website=Games Hardware|accessdate=June 17, 2018|quote=''Nachdem die Fans von Gothic 3 das Rollenspiel bereits mit dem Community Patch 1.7 verbessert haben, arbeiten die Modder nun am Community Story Projekt.''}}</ref> In 2014 an additional patch<ref>{{cite web|url=https://forum.worldofplayers.de/forum/threads/1347969-Release-Gothic-3-v1-75-Update-Pack|title=Release - Gothic 3 v1.75 Update Pack |website=World of Gothic|date=April 20, 2014|accessdate=September 2, 2014|quote="a new Gothic 3 Enhanced Edition v1.75 Update Pack (International)"}}</ref> and a data optimizer<ref>{{cite web|url=https://forum.worldofplayers.de/forum/threads/1225965-Ank%C3%BCndigung-Beta-Release-Gothic3-Clean-Up|title=[Ankündigung & Beta-Release] Gothic3 Clean Up|language=German|website=World of Gothic|date=January 13, 2013|accessdate=January 9, 2015|quote=''Das Tool G3 Clean Up ist dazu bestimmt die Gothic3 typischen Nachladeruckler deutlich zu mildern. Weiterhin kann des den Guru aufgrund von Speichermangel in die Schranken weißen.''}}</ref> for the 1.75.14 version became available fixing some of the remaining issues.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://forum.worldofplayers.de/forum/threads/1265398-Discussion-GENERAL-Gothic-3-FIX-WISHLIST-TOPIC|title=[Discussion] GENERAL Gothic 3 FIX WISHLIST TOPIC|website=World of Gothic|date=June 9, 2013}}</ref>
===Expansion=== {{main|Gothic 3: Forsaken Gods}} On November 21, 2008 [[JoWooD Productions]] released a standalone expansion entitled ''Gothic 3: Forsaken Gods'', developed by Trine Games. ''Gothic 3: Forsaken Gods'' was similar buggy as the original game and was later fixed in an ''Enhanced Edition'' by Mad Vulture Games,<ref name="mvg">{{cite web|url=http://www.madvulture.de/wp/about|title=About MVG|last=Schramm|first=Peter|year=2010|website=Mad Vulture Games|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110326103502/http://www.madvulture.de/wp/about|archivedate=March 26, 2011|accessdate=April 3, 2011|quote=''Being part of the “Community Patch Team” formed to fix the great but bug-baiten “Gothic 3″ game, Mad Vulture Games was taking care of major coordination work, 3D model fixing and lots of other work for the Gothic 3 Addon “Forsaken Gods” Enhanced Edition, also being the producing company.''}}</ref> a company which was created by developers from the game community.
==Reception== {{Video game reviews | MC = 63/100<ref name="mc">{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/pc/gothic-3|title=Gothic 3 for PC Reviews|website=[[Metacritic]]|publisher=CBS Interactive|accessdate=June 17, 2018}}</ref> | 1UP = C<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.1up.com/do/reviewPage?cId=3155631|title=Gothic 3|last=Peckham|first=Matt|date=December 4, 2006|website=[[1UP.com]]|publisher=[[Ziff Davis]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100105122413/http://www.1up.com/do/reviewPage?cId=3155631|archivedate=January 5, 2010|accessdate=June 17, 2018}}</ref> | EuroG = 8/10<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.eurogamer.net/articles/r_gothic3_pc|title=Gothic 3|last=Lyon|first=James|date=October 19, 2006|website=[[Eurogamer]]|publisher=Gamer Network|accessdate=June 17, 2018}}</ref> | GI = 5/10<ref>{{cite magazine|url=http://www.gameinformer.com/NR/exeres/9B47CF5A-E647-4A5D-8FC7-AAD5ACA45C91.htm|title=Gothic 3|last=Biessener|first=Adam|magazine=[[Game Informer]]|publisher=[[GameStop]]|issue=166|date=February 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081005022603/http://www.gameinformer.com/NR/exeres/9B47CF5A-E647-4A5D-8FC7-AAD5ACA45C91.htm|archivedate=October 5, 2008|accessdate=June 17, 2018}}</ref> | GameRev = D<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamerevolution.com/review/37770-gothic-3-review|title=Gothic 3 Review|last=Tackett|first=Tim|date=December 18, 2006|website=[[Game Revolution]]|publisher=[[CraveOnline]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151012040123/http://www.gamerevolution.com/review/gothic-3|archivedate=October 12, 2015|deadurl=no|accessdate=June 17, 2018}}</ref> | GSpot = 7.6/10<ref name="gspot_review" /> | GSpy = {{Rating|1.5|5}}<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pc.gamespy.com/pc/gothic-iii/747441p1.html|title=GameSpy: Gothic 3|last=Rausch|first=Allen|date=November 22, 2006|website=[[GameSpy]]|publisher=Ziff Davis|accessdate=March 19, 2014}}</ref> | GameZone = 7.7/10<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.gamezone.com/reviews/gothic_3_pc_review/|title=Gothic 3 - PC - Review|last=David|first=Mike|date=December 4, 2006|website=GameZone|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081002060233/http://pc.gamezone.com/gzreviews/r25395.htm|archivedate=October 2, 2008|deadurl=no|accessdate=June 17, 2018}}</ref> | IGN = 4.9/10<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2006/11/28/gothic-iii-review|title=Gothic III Review|last=Onyett|first=Charles|date=November 28, 2006|website=[[IGN]]|publisher=Ziff Davis|accessdate=June 17, 2018}}</ref> | PCGUS = 80%<ref>{{cite magazine|title=Gothic 3|magazine=[[PC Gamer]]|publisher=[[Future US]]|volume=14|issue=2|date=February 2007|page=60}}</ref> | XPlay = {{Rating|3|5}}<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.g4tv.com/xplay/reviews/1389/Gothic_3.html|title=Gothic 3|last=Peckham|first=Matt|date=January 30, 2007|website=[[X-Play]]|publisher=[[G4 Media]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081121234713/http://www.g4tv.com/xplay/reviews/1389/Gothic_3.html|archivedate=November 21, 2008|deadurl=yes|accessdate=June 17, 2018}}</ref> }}
''Gothic 3'' was a commercial success, with global sales over 500,000 copies by March 2007.<ref name=sales3>{{cite web|url=https://www.gamesindustry.biz/articles/gothic-3-more-than-500000-units-worldwide-sold|title=''Gothic 3'' - More Than 500,000 Units Worldwide Sold|author=GamesIndustry International|date=March 9, 2007|website=Gamesindustry.biz|publisher=Gamer Network}}</ref><ref>https://web.archive.org/web/20181202031437/http://www.4players.de/4players.php/spielinfonews/PC-CDROM/3266/63163/Gothic_3-500000_verkaufte_Exemplare.html</ref>
The game received "mixed" reviews, according to video game [[review aggregator]] [[Metacritic]].<ref name="mc" /> Prior to its release in early October 2006, Gothic 3 was nominated as the best game of E3 by [[IGN]]. Since the release, most concerns have centered on bugs. ''[[Hyper (magazine)|Hyper]]'''s Daniel Wilks commended the game for its "ton of quests, rewards exploration and approachable combat". However, he criticised it for "system hogging, feeling unfinished and atrocious voice acting".<ref>{{cite magazine|title=Gothic 3|last=Wilks|first=Daniel|magazine=[[Hyper (magazine)|Hyper]]|publisher=[[nextmedia|Next Media Pty Ltd]]|issue=159|date=January 2007|pages=76-77|issn=1320-7458}}</ref>
{{clear}}

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2016}} {{Use Australian English|date=September 2016}} {{Infobox company | name = Hipster Whale Pty Ltd | native_name_lang = <!-- Use ISO 639-1 code, e.g. "fr" for French. For multiple names in different languages, use {{lang|[code]|[name]}}. --> | logo = HipsterWhaleLogo.png | logo_caption = Logo and mascot for Hipster Whale as of September 2016. | type = [[Privately-held company|Private]] | founded = {{start date and age|2014|11|20|df=yes}}<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hipsterwhale.com/press|title=Hipster Whale - Press Kit|publisher=Hipster Whale|accessdate=15 September 2016}}</ref> | hq_location = [[The Arcade (company)|The Arcade]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thearcade.melbourne|title=The Arcade Melbourne|publisher=[[The Arcade (game developers)|The Arcade]]|accessdate=15 September 2015}}</ref> | hq_location_city = [[Melbourne, Australia|Melbourne]] | hq_location_country = [[Australia]] | area_served = Worldwide | key_people = {{unbulleted list|Andy Sum|Matt Hall|Ben Weatherall|Clara Reeves {{small|'''President'''}}}} | industry = [[Video game industry]] | products = {{unbulleted list|''[[Crossy Road]]''|''[[Pac-Man 256]]''|''[[Disney Crossy Road]]''|''[[Shooty Skies]]''}} | services = {{unbulleted list|[[Video game developer|Video game development]]|[[Video game publisher|Video game publishing]]}} | website = [http://hipsterwhale.com hipster.whale] | founders = {{unbulleted list|Andy Sum|Matt Hall}} }} '''Hipster Whale''' is an [[Australia]]n [[Independent video game development|independent]] [[video game developer]] and [[Video game publisher|publisher]] founded in 20 November 2014 by Andy Sum and Matt Hall, shortly before making the game ''[[Crossy Road]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.adcolony.com/blog/2015/01/16/publisher-spotlight-hipster-whale/|title=Publisher Spotlight: Hipster Whale - AdColony|work=AdColony}}</ref> The company has also created the games ''[[Shooty Skies]]'', ''[[Pac-Man 256]]'' (in collaboration with [[Bandai Namco Entertainment]]), and ''[[Crossy Road|Disney Crossy Road]]'' (in collaboration with [[Disney Interactive Studios]]).
==History== [[File:Crossy Road Gameplay.png|thumb|201x201px|''Crossy Road'' gameplay|left]]After meeting at GCAP (Game Center: Asia Pacific) 2013, Andy Sum and Matt Hall decided to make Hipster Whale.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.crossyroad.com/press/|title=Crossy Road Press|publisher=}}</ref> The name came from discussing [[Free-to-play|free-to-play games]] and the word "[[high roller|whale]]" came up in the conversation. Sum was doodling as they were talking and began drawing a whale, which would later become the company's logo. Sum and Hall kept the whale as the mascot for later on.<ref>http://www.redbull.com/us/en/games/stories/1331701011749/crossy-road-hipster-whale-interview</ref>
Hipster Whale's first game, ''Crossy Road'' was planned to take a total of 6 weeks. But after seeing its potential, the developers spent more than 12 weeks developing it. ''Crossy Road'' was inspired by linear movement games (modern successors to classic [[platform games]])such as ''[[Temple Run]]'', ''[[Flappy Bird]]'', ''[[Disco Zoo]]'', ''[[Frogger]]'', ''[[Skylanders]]'', ''[[Tiny Wings]]'', ''[[Subway Surfers]]'', and ''[[Fez (video game)|Fez]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/KlickTock/status/538471575838674945|title=Matt Hall|work=Twitter}}</ref> The name and concept of the game is based on the joke "[[Why did the chicken cross the road?]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/digital-life/macman/more-than-fun-and-games-with-local-developers-20150304-13usxe|title=More than fun and games with local developers|work=The Sydney Morning Herald}}</ref>
On 22 May 2015, [[Bandai Namco Entertainment]] and Hipster Whale announced ''[[Pac-Man 256]]'', which featured [[Pac-Man (character)|Pac-Man]] trying to escape ghosts and overcome a glitch while performing the same mechanics as the [[Pac-Man|1980 video game]], with the glitch based on the [[Pac-Man#Kill screen|Level 256 glitch]] from the original arcade game,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://toucharcade.com/2015/05/22/pac-man-256-crossy-road/|title='Pac-Man 256' by Hipster Whale is 'Pac-Man' Meets 'Crossy Road'|last=Dotson|first=Carter|date=22 May 2015|work=TouchArcade|access-date=15 September 2016|via=}}</ref> but with upgrades and [[freemium]] [[Microtransaction|purchases]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://kotaku.com/endless-pac-man-is-really-fun-even-though-you-can-neve-1725723440|title=Pac-Man 256 Is Endless Pac-Man With A Fun, Glitchy Twist|last=Hamilton|first=Kirk|date=21 August 2015|work=[[Kotaku]]|access-date=15 September 2016|via=[[Univision Communications]]}}</ref> On 20 August, the game was released, with the game then being released on [[Microsoft Windows]], [[PlayStation 4]] and [[Xbox One]] on 22 June 2016<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://venturebeat.com/2016/06/22/pac-man-256-is-munching-endless-pellets-on-ps4-xbox-one-and-steam-right-now/|title=Pac-Man 256 is munching endless pellets on PS4, Xbox One, and Steam|last=Wilson|first=Jason|date=22 June 2016|work=[[VentureBeat]]|access-date=15 September 2016|via=}}</ref>
In March 2016, Hipster Whale announced a spin-off of ''Crossy Road'', ''[[Disney Crossy Road]]'', which would be published by [[Disney Interactive Studios]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://creative.vic.gov.au/news/2016/disney-and-hipster-whale-announce-new-game|title=Disney and Hipster Whale Announce New Game|last=|first=|date=17 March 2016|website=|publisher=Creative Victoria|access-date=15 September 2016}}</ref> On 20 July, the company announced its move into [[Video game publisher|video game publishing]], and appointed former [[Atari]] and [[Krome Studios Melbourne]] employee Clara Reeves as the [[President (corporate title)|President]] of Hipster Whale, who recently worked at [[Film Victoria]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.gamesindustry.biz/articles/2016-07-20-crossy-road-studio-hipster-whale-expands-into-publishing|title=Crossy Road studio Hipster Whale expands into publishing|last=Brightman|first=James|date=20 July 2016|work=Gamesindustry.biz|access-date=15 September 2016|via=[[Eurogamer]]}}</ref> On 7 September, the company released an update towards ''Disney Crossy Road'', which added ''[[Monsters, Inc.]]'' characters to the game and a mode called the "Weekend Challenge".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.mobipicker.com/disney-crossy-road-guide-monster-inc/|title=Disney Crossy Road Guide – Monster Inc. Update, Unlock All Characters, Weekend Challenge and More|last=|first=|date=8 September 2016|work=MobiPicker|access-date=15 September 2016|via=}}</ref>
== Products == {| class="wikitable" !Year !Title !Genre !Platform |- |2014 |''[[Crossy Road]]'' | rowspan="4" |[[Platform game#Endless running game|Endless]] [[Arcade game|arcade]] [[mobile game]] |[[iOS]], [[tvOS]], [[Android (operating system)|Android]], [[Windows Phone]] |- | rowspan="2" |2015 |''[[Pac-Man 256]]'' |[[iOS]], [[Android (operating system)|Android]], [[Microsoft Windows]], [[PlayStation 4]], [[Xbox One]], [[OS X]], [[Linux]] |- |''[[Shooty Skies]]'' |[[iOS]], [[Android (operating system)|Android]] |- |2016 |''[[Disney Crossy Road]]'' |[[iOS]], [[Android (operating system)|Android]], [[Windows Phone]], |}

{{Infobox company | name = Georgian Film Studio
ქართული ფილმი | logo = | caption = | type = [[Joint-stock company|JSC]] | foundation = 1921 | location = [[Tbilisi]], [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]] | key_people = [[Rezo Chkheidze]] ([[Chairman]]) | num_employees = 800 | industry = [[Film industry|Motion pictures]]
[[Animated film]]s | products = [[Film|Motion pictures]]
[[Television program]]s | revenue = | homepage = www.georgianfilm.ge }} '''Georgian Film Studio''' ({{lang-ka|ქართული ფილმი}} Georgian Film; {{lang-ru|Грузия-фильм}}) is one of world's oldest film studios that has produced 800 feature, made-for-TV and short films, 600 documentaries, and 300 animation movies. During Soviet times, the studio was one of the most active places for film production. Having grown organically from the merger of several film production companies that operated in the beginning of the twentieth century in Tbilisi, the studio had been renamed several times before becoming Georgian Film (Gruziya-Film in Russian) in 1953. Sitting on 9.75 hectares (24 acres) of prime land in Tbilisi, Georgian Film Studios offers several sound stages, recording and editing facilities, various production services, modern equipment and professional crews. Georgian Film was founded in 1921 {{cite book|last=Rollberg|first=Peter|title=Historical Dictionary of Russian and Soviet Cinema|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Cuw1vHuxITYC&printsec=frontcover#PPA274,M1|year=2008|pages=274–277|isbn=0-8108-6072-4}} ==References== ==External links== *[http://animator.ru/db/?ver=eng&p=show_studia&sid=22&sp=2 Catalogue of the studio's 207 animated films] {{Soviet Film Studios}} [[Category:Cinema of Georgia (country)]] [[Category:Film production companies of the Soviet Union]] [[Category:Film studios]] [[Category:Media companies established in 1921]] [[Category:1921 establishments in Georgia (country)]] {{film-studio-stub}}

revision.text:
'''Lokomotyv Stadium''' is a name of several stadiums in Ukraine.
* [[Lokomotyv Stadium (Poltava)]], a stadium in [[Poltava]] * [[Lokomotyv Republican Sports Complex]], a stadium in [[Simferopol]] * Lokomotyv Stadium, a stadium in [[Korosten]] * Lokomotyv Stadium, former name of Hirka Stadium in [[Ivano-Frankivsk]] * Lokomotyv Stadium, former name of [[Tsentralnyi Stadion (Vinnytsia)]] in [[Vinnytsia]]
{{disambig}} [[Category:Sports venues in Ukraine]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.2)
revision.text:
'''Media meshing''' is the process of using one of the [[Mass media|media]], such as a [[blog]] or a [[website]], to enhance the experience of another medium, such as a newspaper article or a fictional television program.<ref name='clickz2005'>[http://www.clickz.com/showPage.html?page=3515526 Media Meshing: An Evolution in Media Consumption], Pete Lerma, [[clickZ]], 2005-Jun-28, retrieved 2007-Apr-14</ref> "Meshing" may describe activities and motivations of an information receiver which are completely independent of the intentions of the source of that information. "Meshing" may also be used to describe the activities of an information provider, who may intentionally encourage consumer engagement by using multiple media or channels of information exchange related to a product or organization, as in an integrated [[advertising campaign]]. Strictly, in both cases, "media meshing" ultimately describes the ''behaviour'' of the person ''receiving'' the information.
When the meshing of media sources is encouraged by the source itself, as is often the case with commercial products and special interest promotions, media meshing may be better described as [[integrated media]].<ref>[http://www.integratedmedia.org/nav.cfm?cat=15&subcat=116&subsub=126 Integrated Media Association] retrieved 2007-Apr-14</ref> This describes the activity desired by commercial entities when they encourage web traffic through non-web media such as billboards or newspaper articles in a comprehensive [[advertising campaign]].<ref name='clickz2006'>[http://www.clickz.com/showPage.html?page=3623563 American Express' Media Meshing], Pete Lerma, [[clickZ]], 2006-Oct-03, retrieved 2007-Apr-14</ref>
However, from the perspective of the information [[consumer]], Lerma describes that meshing represents a way to experience media which is fundamentally different from the way people interacted with mass media in the past. When the participants themselves choose the channels, pieces, sources, and specific media that they use to enhance or disassemble the first piece of media they encounter, especially when these are perceived to be mostly independent sources, the result is an enriched self-discovery experience with a level of engagement not possible from even the most well designed guided experiences. Meshing goes beyond simply [[mutually inclusive public relations]] across media channels, pieces, and [[product placement]]. [[Broadband]] technology and diversity of online services have increased the accessibility and prevalence of simultaneous media experiences to the point where some would argue there is a new, more demanding and more inquisitive, incarnation of information [[consumer]]s.<ref name='omd2005'>[http://publications.mediapost.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=Articles.san&s=29314&Nid=13055&p=301415 Yahoo!: Internet Users 'Mesh' Web With Television] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070227064523/http://publications.mediapost.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=Articles.san |date=2007-02-27 }} Wendy Davis, 2005-Apr-19, retrieved 2007-Apr-14</ref> The richness of experience in meshing becomes even more evident when information receivers puts their new views and interpretations back into the media by posting or answering questions on a discussion forum or blog, publishing a formal in-depth response, or creating an independent fan site. In cases like these, the persons may be called information [[prosumer]]s, as they are both consuming information from various sources and producing a web of related information for other "meshers" to ''consume'' (or ''prosumers'' to mesh).
<!-- these next statements are carefully constructed to be true, using weasle words I admit, but are important concepts in this article, and I think, could be substantiated by an expert in information and knowledge and media --> It is arguable, however, that this is the traditional approach of historians and scientists to information sources, and that what is new is the speed and ease with which cross-referencing and elaboration can be achieved with the media delivery and display technology that is used, and the amount of time invested in multi-source research by the non-specialized population. It is also arguable that multi-form/multi-source information gathering only "seems" new when contrasted to the recent era of single-voice and non-interactive commercial television and radio information broadcasting. It is also important to note that if the sources are not chosen carefully to be as [[orthogonal]] as possible, media meshing will result in a false reassurance of the "facts" presented by the single-voice of the original articles, but it would still technically be media meshing (i.e., confirming a [[CNN]] television story about an event in London by meshing the [[CNN.com]] web-site, [[BBC]] radio, and ''[[The Guardian]]'' newspaper will probably confirm the original facts, but a different set of facts may be forthcoming from an email to a friend who lives there or from reading a blog from a beat-cop in the area.)
==Engagement==
{{quote|''Using the Web in this fashion--dubbed "media meshing" by the report--"fulfills a need to become more deeply involved with hobbies, interests or stories that kindle passionate involvement," states the report.''|Wendy Davis, Online Media Daily <ref name='omd2005'/>}}
{{quote|''...the Yahoo/mediaedge:cia research shows people with broadband don't necessarily make big shifts in their [[media consumption]] in terms of time spent. Instead, they change how they use other forms of media in conjunction with the Internet. They use the Internet to maximize their engagement with other media.''|Pete Lerma, clickZ <ref name='clickz2005'/>}}
==Advertising== {{quote|''Producers retain their shows interactive rights and integrate "experience triggers" into them''|Pete Lerma, clickZ <ref name='clickz2005'/>}}
==Activities== The following activities, while perhaps not unique to media meshing, are characteristic of this type of 'enhanced' media consumption * look up Web sites related to TV programming <ref name='omd2005'/> * look up Web sites mentioned on TV ads <ref name='omd2005'/> * take part in online polls mentioned on television <ref name='omd2005'/> * access more than one type of media simultaneously <ref name='omd2005'/> * ''Communicating'' becomes ''socializing''<ref name='clickz2005'/> - email, instant chat and online communities bring families and friends together in real ways, replacing other forms of socializing * ''Sound bites'' become ''full stories''<ref name='clickz2005'/> - a five-second headline on the evening news turns into four hours of deep multi-source coverage and 14 hours of discussion online * ''Just for fun'' becomes ''personal entertainment''<ref name='clickz2005'/> - try correcting a few pages in Wikipedia for fun, for example * read stories in magazines and newspapers, then go online to get multiple angles on the same stories <ref name='clickz2005'/> * watch a reality TV show, then go online to get character bios, behind-the-scenes information <ref name='clickz2005'/><ref name='omd2005'/>
== Examples== <!-- caution, this should not be a link-farm or directory [[WP:NOT#DIR]] I think we would like a small number of good examples or anecdotes, preferably with good Wikipedia articles about them. If you find a really good example, perhaps consider replacing a poorer example if it makes the same point. --> * In news, using [http://en.wikinews.org WikiNews] and Wikipedia together to investigate, confirm, and gain a deeper understanding of broadcast news stories from a commercial or publicly funded source
==See also== <!-- moved some see also terms right into the intro paragraph text --> * [[Wikipedian]] * [[Tag (metadata)]] * [[Web 2.0]]
==References== <references/>
==External links== * [http://www.mecglobal.com/output/Page1323.asp Report - It's a broadband life] mediaedge:cia 2005-Apr-19, retrieved 2007-Apr-14 * [http://advertising.yahoo.com/central/summitseries/archive.html?event=broadbandlife_05 Yahoo! It's a Broadband Life]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Media Meshing}} [[Category:Mass media]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Infobox company | name = Mixamo Inc. | logo = Mixamo Logo.png | logo_size = 300px | type = [[Corporation]] | industry = [[Interactive entertainment]] | foundation = 2008 | founder = Stefano Corazza, Nazim Kareemi | location_city = [[San Francisco]] | location_country = United States | area_served = | key_people = | products = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | owner = | num_employees = 20 | parent = [[Adobe Systems]] | homepage = {{Official website|http://www.mixamo.com/}} }}
'''Mixamo''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|m|ɪ|k|s|ə|m|oʊ}}) is a [[3D computer graphics]] technology company. Based in San Francisco, the company develops and sells web-based services for [[3D model|3D character]] animation. Mixamo's technologies use [[machine learning]] methods to automate the steps of the character animation process, including [[3D modeling]] to rigging and [[3D animation]].
Mixamo is spun-off of [[Stanford University]] and has raised over $11 million from investors [[Granite Ventures]], Keynote Ventures, Stanford University and [[Advanced Micro Devices|AMD Ventures]].<ref name=venturebeat1>{{cite news |title=Mixamo debuts Fuse character creation tool on Steam using Valve’s Team Fortress 2 characters |author=Dean Takahashi |date=November 7, 2013 |publisher=Venture Beat |url=https://venturebeat.com/2013/11/07/mixamo-debuts-fuse-character-creation-tool-on-steam-using-valves-team-fortress-2-characters/ |accessdate=November 23, 2014}}</ref> Mixamo was acquired by [[Adobe Systems]] on June 1, 2015.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Unlocking The Power of 3D for The Creative Community – Adobe Acquires Mixamo « Adobe Creative Cloud|url = https://blogs.adobe.com/creativecloud/unlocking-the-power-of-3d-for-the-creative-community/|website = blogs.adobe.com|accessdate = 2015-06-04}}</ref>
==History== Mixamo was founded in 2008 by Stefano Corazza and Nazim Kareemi as a spin-off of Stanford University's Biomotion Lab,<ref name=venturebeat1/><ref name=techcrunch1>{{cite news |title=Mixamo Is Building A Platform For Game Developers To Create And Animate 3D Characters |author=Kim-Mai Cutler |date=July 23, 2014 |publisher=Tech Crunch |url=https://techcrunch.com/2013/07/23/mixamo/ |accessdate=November 23, 2014}}</ref> and started out as a cloud-based service offering animations and automatic character rigging.<ref name=cgworld1>{{cite news |title=Evolving Characters |author=Kathleen Maher |date=May 21, 2014 |publisher=Computer Graphics World |url=http://www.cgw.com/Press-Center/In-Focus/2014/Evolving-Characters.aspx |accessdate=November 23, 2014}}</ref> It launched its first online animation service in 2009. In 2010, Mixamo worked with Evolver to provide characters to customers.<ref name=cgworld1/> Later [[Autodesk]] acquired Evolver and made it proprietary, but Mixamo had already begun work on its own character creation service.<ref name=cgworld1/>
Mixamo released its automatic rigging service in 2011. That was followed by the launch of its real-time facial animation product, Face Plus, in 2013,<ref name=technewsworld>{{cite news |title=Face Plus Gives Digital Characters Heart and Soul |author=Rachelle Dragani |date=August 29, 2013 |publisher=TechNews World |url=http://www.technewsworld.com/story/78767.html |accessdate=November 23, 2014}}</ref> and the official launch of its Fuse 3D character creator software in March 2014.<ref name=developonline>{{cite news |title=Mixamo launching Fuse 1.0 |author=Craig Chapple |date=March 12, 2014 |publisher=Develop Online |url=https://www.develop-online.net/news/mixamo-launching-fuse-1-0-next-week/0190316 |accessdate=November 23, 2014}}</ref> In August 2014, Mixamo launched a new pricing structure.<ref name=cgworld2>{{cite news |title=Mixamo Offers New Pricing Structure |date=August 20, 2014 |publisher=Computer Graphics World |url=http://www.cgw.com/Press-Center/News/2014/Mixamo-Offers-New-Pricing-Structure.aspx |accessdate=November 23, 2014}}</ref>
==Fuse== [[File:Fuse Character Creator Carousel.png|thumb|right|Models created with Fuse.]] In March 2014, Mixamo officially launched [[Fuse Character Creator]] at [[Game Developers Conference]].<ref name=developonline/> Fuse stems out of the research done by Siddhartha Chaudhuri<ref>[http://vladlen.info/publications/probabilistic-reasoning-for-assembly-based-3d-modeling/ Siddhartha Chaudhuri]</ref> which originated within Vladlen Koltun's research group at Stanford and Substance technology from Allegorithmic.<ref name=slashgear>{{cite news |title=Mixamo Fuse universal expendable 3-D character creator launches on Steam |author=Shane McGlaun |date=November 8, 2013 |publisher=SlashGear |url=http://www.slashgear.com/mixamo-fuse-universal-expendable-3-d-character-creator-launches-on-steam-08304713/ |accessdate=November 8, 2013}}</ref> An early version of the service had been released in November 2013.<ref name=gamasutra2013>{{cite news |title=Fuse adds easy character creation to Steam |author=Kris Ligman |date=November 8, 2013 |publisher=Gamasutra |url=http://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/204434/Fuse_adds_easy_character_creation_to_Steam.php |accessdate=November 23, 2014}}</ref>
It allows users to create a 3D character by assembling customizable body parts, clothing and textures together.<ref name=gfxspeak>{{cite news |title=Mixamo builds out to end to end products, adds upgrade in time for GDC |author=Kathleen Maher |date=March 12, 2014 |publisher=GraphicSpeak |url=http://gfxspeak.com/2014/03/12/mixamo-products-upgrades/ |accessdate=November 23, 2014}}</ref> Those characters can then be exported into other [[3D modeling|3D model]] software packages or [[game engines|game engine]].<ref name=gfxspeak/> In March 2014, Mixamo launched Fuse 1.0 on Steam with the ability of importing and integrating user generated content in the character creation system.<ref name=cinemablend>{{cite news |title=Mixamo Releases Fuse, Character Creation Tool On Steam |author=William Usher |date=March 30, 2014 |publisher=Cinema Blend |url=http://www.cinemablend.com/games/Mixamo-Releases-Fuse-Character-Creation-Tool-Steam-63079.html |accessdate=November 23, 2014}}</ref> Fuse was updated to allow the importation and editing of character models generated by Microsoft's Kinect 2.0 in August of that year.<ref name=gamasutra2014>{{cite news |title=Mixamo's Fuse makes modeling people easier with Kinect v2 support |author=Alex Wawro |date=August 7, 2014 |publisher=Gamasutra |url=http://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/222858/Mixamos_Fuse_makes_modeling_people_easier_with_Kinect_v2_support.php |accessdate=November 23, 2014}}</ref>
==Rigging service== Mixamo also provides an online, automatic model rigging service known as the Auto-Rigger, which was the industry's first online rigging service. The AutoRigger applies machine learning to understand where the limbs of a 3D model are and to insert a "skeleton", or rig, into the 3D model as well as calculating the skinning weights. The service can take up to 2 minutes.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.mcvuk.com/development/digging-into-rigging-mixamos-character-service-explored|title=Digging into rigging: Mixamo's character service explored|work=MCV|access-date=2018-01-30|language=en-us}}</ref>
==3D Character Animation== Mixamo's online services include an animation store featuring downloadable 3D models and animation sequences. The animations were created at Mixamo using [[motion capture]] and cleaned up by key frame animators. All its animations work with characters created in Fuse and/or rigged with Mixamo's AutoRigger.
==Real-time facial animation== [[File:Unplugged real-time animated short.png|thumb|right|Screenshot from "Unplugged": real-time facial animation from single camera and blendshape animation running in [[Unity (game engine)|Unity]] game engine.]]
August 2013, Mixamo released Face Plus, a [[game development tool]] that allows users to record [[facial animation]] data of themselves using a standard webcam and apply the animation to a character inside the [[Unity (game engine)|Unity]] [[game engine]] in real-time.<ref name=technewsworld/><ref name=tropicalpost/> Face Plus was briefly included in the keynote presentation at the Unite conference in Vancouver. The technology was developed in collaboration with [[Advanced Micro Devices|AMD]].<ref name=gfxspeak/> and uses [[Graphics processing unit|GPU]] acceleration.<ref name=tropicalpost>{{cite news |title=Generate realistic Animation using Mixamo’s Face plus |date=September 6, 2013 |publisher=TropicalPost |url=http://tropicalpost.com/generate-realistic-animation-using-mixamos-face-plus/ |accessdate=November 23, 2014}}</ref>
The animated short "Unplugged" was created using Face Plus technology and as of April 2014 has won several awards.<ref>http://bestshorts.net/?page_id=163</ref>
== References == {{reflist|2}}
==External links== * [https://techcrunch.com/2013/08/28/mixamo-face-plus/ "Mixamo’s Facial Expression Capturing Technology Helps Indie Developers Speed Up Character Animation"] from [[Techcrunch]] * [http://www.mixamo.com Official site] * [http://www.mixamo.com/unplugged Unplugged – Official site]
[[Category:Entertainment software]] [[Category:Software companies based in California]] [[Category:Animation software]] [[Category:Stanford University]] [[Category:American companies established in 2008]] [[Category:Companies based in San Francisco]]

revision.text:
{{about|the THQ game|the Capcom game|MotoGP '07 (PS2)|the 2007 MotoGP season|2007 Grand Prix motorcycle racing season}} {{Infobox video game |title=MotoGP '07 |image = MotoGP 07 Xbox360.jpg |caption= |developer = [[Black Rock Studio|Climax Racing]]
Rockpool Games (mobile) |publisher = [[THQ]] |designer = |engine = |released = '''Mobile'''
{{vgrelease|NA|Summer 2007}}'''Xbox 360'''
{{Video game release|EU|August 24, 2007|NA|August 27, 2007|AU|September 2007}}'''Windows'''
{{vgrelease|EU|September 28, 2007|AUS|October 11, 2007}} |genre = [[Racing video game|Racing]] |modes = [[Single-player]], [[Multiplayer video game|multiplayer]] |platforms = [[Xbox 360]]
[[Microsoft Windows]]
[[Mobile phone]] }} '''''MotoGP '07''''' is the fifth game in [[THQ]]'s MotoGP series for [[Xbox 360]], [[Microsoft Windows]] and [[mobile phone]]s (the latter released as '''''MotoGP 4'''''). The purchase of the [[Black Rock Studio|Climax Racing]] studio, developer of most of the previous titles in the series, from Climax Studios by [[Disney Interactive Studios]][https://web.archive.org/web/20061008173035/http://www.computerandvideogames.com/article.php?id=146839] led to speculation over who would be developing the game. However, a promo video on the [[Xbox Live Marketplace]] confirmed that Climax Studios were still involved in ''MotoGP '07''. ==Features== ''MotoGP '07'' features complete rider and team data, new 800[[Cubic centimetre|cc]] [[Grand Prix motorcycle racing|MotoGP]] bikes and all 18 circuit of the [[2007 Grand Prix motorcycle racing season|2007 MotoGP season]]. The title also features interactive track-side crowds, on-line tournament features, on-line "[[Vehicle title|pink slip]]" racing, and a revamped Extreme mode. The revamped Extreme mode allows for over one million possible bike customizations. In addition, minor gameplay changes have been made to the [[Car handling|handling]] and [[Brake|braking]] to allow for easier player accessibility. Changes to [[acceleration]] and [[Acceleration|deceleration]] have been made to add to the realism which will make turns easier to navigate through. Slight [[fishtailing]] with hard braking has been put in to give a better feel for the handling of the bike and to let the player know how effective their braking is.{{cite web |last=Brudvig |first=Erik |date=March 2, 2007 |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2007/03/02/motogp-07-hands-on |title=MotoGP '07 Hands-On |publisher=IGN |accessdate=June 21, 2016}} Also, the ability of the player to customise their bikes is greatly increased. In Extreme mode the player can upgrade their bike with various performance modifications: carbon brakes, race exhausts, magnesium/carbon wheels etc. In Grand Prix mode, the customisation is limited to visual upgrades, though ''MotoGP'07'' now allows players greater control over the appearance of their bike. Despite this, some players have complained that the visual modifications are still fairly restrictive - the main criticism is that the custom paintwork option still restricts the player to the same limited amount of customisation as the previous games, despite the fact that the overall visual modification option has been overhauled. This leaves the player unable to design or customise the paint on their bike to approximate the level of design detail achieved by other AI racers.. Whether this issue will be resolved in future patches is not known. In addition to this the PC version of the game features a corrupt model of the Yamaha M1 with the rear cowling misformed visible on Rossi and Edwards' bikes. Also the crowds in grandstands no longer work with post 2010's graphics drivers on the PC and shimmer. ===Ilmor GP=== The game features Ilmor GP to ride but In real life Ilmor rider Jeremy McWilliams crashed before the first Round of the season in Qatar, resulting in him not Being able to take part in the race. Andrew Pitt, the second Rider, raced alone. However, Ilmor GP does not appear in more races since Ilmor retired from the 2007 Championship after the first GP in Qatar. However, Jeremy McWilliams and Andrew Pitt and the Ilmor GP bike are available to use as a playable driver and bike in the championship mode and race mode and in the quick races In championship mode, the Ilmor GP team was removed to avoid running against them, In sports race, you can use the Ilmor GP team to customize it and play with it but like the championship mode, the Ilmor GP team is removed and we will not be able to race against them. In quick race, one rider IA will be replaced random for Andrew Pitt, since the game only has 19 bikes at a time, 20 bikes for the sports race mode. ==Release== ''MotoGP '07'' had a somewhat protracted release in the United Kingdom. While the Xbox release proceeded as planned, the PC version was delayed twice: originally delayed until the first week of September, and then delayed again until the eventual release date of September 28.{{citation needed|date=June 2016}} ==Reception== {{Video game reviews | MOB = true | PC = true | X360 = true | na = true | Edge_X360 = 7/10{{cite journal |author=Edge staff |title=MotoGP '07 (X360) 2016}} | OXM_X360 = 8.5/10{{cite journal |title=MotoGP '07 |magazine=[[Official Xbox Magazine]] |date=October 2007 |page=79}} | OXMUK_X360 = 7/10{{cite journal |last=McAllister |first=Gillen revision.comment: /* top */clean up, replaced: Journal of the neurological sciences → Journal of the Neurological Sciences
revision.text:
'''Musical hallucinations''' fall under the category of [[auditory hallucinations]] and describe a disorder in which a sound is perceived as instrumental music, sounds, or songs. It is a very rare disorder, reporting only 0.16% in a cohort study of 3,678 individuals.<ref name ="Evers">{{cite journal |last=Evers |first=S |author2=Ellger, T |title=The clinical spectrum of musical hallucinations |journal=Journal of the Neurological Sciences |year=2004 |volume=227 |issue=1 |pages=55–65 |pmid=15546592 |doi=10.1016/j.jns.2004.08.004}}</ref>
== Description of disorder == In 73 individual cases reviewed by Evers and Ellger, 57 patients heard tunes that were familiar, while 5 heard unfamiliar tunes. These tunes ranged from religious pieces to childhood favorites, and also included popular songs from the radio. Vocal and instrumental forms of classical music were also identified in some patients. Keshavan found that the consistent feature of musical hallucinations was that it represented a personal memory trace. Memory traces refer to anything that may seem familiar to the patient, which indicate why certain childhood or familiar songs were heard.<ref name="Evers" /><ref name="Keshavan" />
== Causes == Investigators have successfully narrowed down the major factors that are associated with musical hallucinations. Evers and Ellgers compiled a significant portion of musical hallucination articles, case studies etc. and were able to categorize five major etiologies:
* [[Hypoacusis]] * [[Musical hallucinations#Psychiatric disorders|Psychiatric disorders]] * [[Focal brain lesion]] * [[Epilepsy]] * [[Substance intoxication|Intoxication]]
=== Hypoacusis === Hypoacusis is defined as impairment in hearing or deafness. Hypoacusis is one of five etiologies of musical hallucinations, and is the most common in the case studies reviewed by Evers and Ellgers.<ref name="Evers" /> According to Sanchez et al. 2011, there have been suggestions that pontine lesions could alter the central auditory system's function causing hypoacusis and musical hallucinations.<ref name="Hammeke">{{cite journal |last=Hammeke |first=TA |author2=McQuillen, MP |author3=Cohen, BA |title=Musical hallucinations associated with acquired deafness |journal=Journal of Neurology, Neurosurgery, and Psychiatry |year=1983 |volume=46 |issue=6 |pages=570–2 |pmid=6875592 |pmc=1027453 |doi=10.1136/jnnp.46.6.570}}</ref><ref name="Sanchez">{{cite journal |last=Sanchez |first=TG|author2=Rocha, SC |author3=Knobel, KA |author4=Kii, MA |author5=Santos, RM |author6= Pereira, CB |title=Musical hallucination associated with hearing loss |journal=Arquivos de neuro-psiquiatria |year=2011 |volume=69 |issue=2B |pages=395–400 |pmid=21625772 |doi=10.1590/s0004-282x2011000300024}}</ref>
=== Psychiatric disorders === A case study by Janakiraman et al. 2006, revealed a 93‑year‑old woman with [[major depressive disorder]] who experienced musical hallucinations while treated with [[electroconvulsive therapy]] (ECT). Investigators found that the patient's depression symptoms were inversely related to her hallucinations and primarily stemmed from the ECT treatment. The patient had no known abnormalities in hearing, suggesting that musical hallucinations could arise from a variety of sources including psychiatric illnesses. After a complete course of ECT, her hallucinations dissipated, also suggesting that they can be acute.<ref name="Janaki">{{cite journal |last=Janakiraman |first=R |author2=Wildgoose, K |author3=Seelam, K |title=ECT associated musical hallucinations in an elderly patient: a case report |journal=Annals of General Psychiatry |year=2006 |volume=5 |pages=10 |pmid=16889667 |doi=10.1186/1744-859X-5-10 |pmc=1557851}}</ref>
According to Evers and Ellgers, some other major psychiatric disorders that contribute to musical hallucinations include [[schizophrenia]] and depression. Some patients who have schizophrenia experience musical hallucinations due to their ongoing psychosis, but there are some cases that do so without psychosis. There are also a very small percentage of musical hallucination cases due to [[obsessive-compulsive disorder]] (OCD).<ref name="Evers" />
=== Focal brain lesions === Among the handful of cases that Evers and Ellgers studied, major lesion sites included the temporal cortex; however, the specific location and laterality (left vs. right temporal cortex) was variable. Many cases of focal brain lesions had comorbidity with hearing impairment (see hypoacusis), epileptic activity and intoxication.<ref name="Evers" /> There have also been several findings of acute musical hallucinations in patients with dorsal [[pons]] lesions post-stroke and [[encephalitis]] potentially due to disruption of connections between the [[sensory cortex]] and [[reticular formation]].<ref name="Schielke">{{cite journal |last=Schielke |first=E |author2=Reuter, U |author3=Hoffmann, O |author4= Weber, JR |title=Musical hallucinations with dorsal pontine lesions |journal=Neurology |year=2000 |volume=55 |issue=3 |pages=454–5 |pmid=10932294 |doi=10.1212/wnl.55.3.454}}</ref>
=== Epilepsy === Epileptic brain activity in musical hallucinations originates in the left or right temporal lobe.<ref name="Evers" /> In a specific case studied by Williams et al. 2008, a patient who received a left temporal lobectomy in order to treat epilepsy was diagnosed with musical hallucinations post-surgery. The patient also had multiple additional risk factors that could have accounted for the hallucinations including mild neuropsychiatric dysfunction and [[tinnitus]].<ref name="Williams">{{cite journal |last=Williams |first=VG |author2=Tremont, G |author3=Blum, AS |title=Musical hallucinations after left temporal lobectomy |journal=Cognitive and Behavioral Neurology |year=2008 |volume=21 |issue=1 |pages=38–40 |pmid=18327022 |doi=10.1097/WNN.0b013e318165a9e1}}</ref>
=== Intoxication === Intoxication accounts for a small percentage of musical hallucination cases. Intoxication leads to either withdrawal or inflammatory encephalopathy, which are major contributors to musical hallucinations. Some of the drugs that have been found to relate to musical hallucinations include salicylates, benzodiazepines, pentoxifylline, propranolol, clomipramine, amphetamine, quinine, imipramine, a phenothiazine, carbamazepine, marijuana, paracetamol, phenytoin, procaine, and alcohol. General anesthesia has also been association with musical hallucinations.<ref name="Evers" /> In a case study by Gondim et al. 2010, a seventy–seven-year-old woman with [[Parkinson's disease]] (PD) was administered [[amantadine]] after a year of various other antiparkinsonian treatments. Two days into her treatment, she started to experience musical hallucinations, which consisted of four musical pieces. The music persisted until three days after cessation of the drug. Although the patient was taking other medications at the same time, the timing of onset and offset suggested that amantadine either had a synergistic effect with the other drugs or simply caused the hallucinations. Although the case wasn't specific to intoxication, it leads to the idea that persons with PD who are treated with certain drugs can experience musical hallucinations.<ref name="Gondim">{{cite journal |last1=Gondim |first1=Francisco de Assis Aquino |last2=Costa |first2=Helida A. |last3=Taunay |first3=Tauily C.D. |last4=de Oliveira |first4=Gisele R. |last5=Ferreira |first5=Jamile Magalhães |last6=Rola |first6=Francisco H. |title=Transient amantadine‑induced musical hallucinations in a patient with Parkinson’s disease |journal=Movement Disorders |publisher=Wiley-Blackwell |year=2010 |volume=25 |issue=10 |pages=1505–1506 |pmid=20629118 |doi=10.1002/mds.22553 |issn=0885-3185}}</ref>
==Imaging == [[Positron emission tomography]] (PET) and [[functional magnetic resonance imaging]] (fMRI) show that musical hallucinations activate a wide variety of areas in the brain including the following: auditory areas, [[motor cortex]], visual areas, [[basal ganglia]], [[brainstem]], [[pons]], [[tegmentum]], [[cerebellum]], [[Hippocampus|hippocampi]], [[amygdala]], and peripheral auditory system.<ref name="Sacks" />
== Treatment == To date, there is no successful method of treatment that "cures" musical hallucinations. There have been successful therapies in single cases that have ameliorated the hallucinations. Some of these successes include drugs such as neuroleptics, antidepressants, and certain anticonvulsive drugs. A musical hallucination was alleviated, for example, by antidepressant medications given to patients with depression.<ref name="Evers" /> Sanchez reported that some authors have suggested that the use of hearing aids may improve musical hallucination symptoms.<ref name="Sanchez" /> They believed that the external environment influences the auditory hallucinations, showing worsening of symptoms in quieter environments than in noisier ones.<ref name="Hammeke" /><ref name="Miller">{{cite journal |last=Miller |first=TC |author2=Crosby, TW |title=Musical hallucinations in a deaf elderly patient |journal=Annals of Neurology |date=Mar 1979 |volume=5 |issue=3 |pages=301–2 |pmid=443762 |doi=10.1002/ana.410050314}}</ref><ref name="Ross">{{cite journal |last=Ross |first=Elliott D. |title=Musical Hallucinations in Deafness |journal=Journal of the American Medical Association |date=1975-02-10 |volume=231 |issue=6 |pages=620 |doi=10.1001/jama.1975.03240180056018 |pmid=1172847}}</ref> Oliver Sacks' patient, Mrs. O'C, reported being in an "ocean of sound" despite being in a quiet room due to a small thrombosis or infarction in her right temporal lobe. After treatment, Mrs. O'C was relinquished of her musical experience but said that, "I do miss the old songs. Now, with lots of them, I can't even recall them. It was like being given back a forgotten bit of my childhood again." Sacks also reported another elderly woman, Mrs. O'M, who had a mild case of deafness and reported hearing musical pieces. When she was treated with anticonvulsive medications, her musical hallucinations ceased but when asked if she missed them, she said "Not on your life."<ref name="Sacks1">{{cite book |last=Sacks |first=Oliver |title=The man who mistook his wife for a hat and other clinical tales |year=1998 |publisher=Simon & Schuster |location=New York, NY |isbn=978-0-684-85394-9 |edition=1st Touchstone}}</ref>
== History== According to [[Oliver Sacks]]' ''[[Hallucinations (book)|Hallucinations]]'', the first known medical report of musical hallucinations was published in 1846, by French alienist Jules Baillarger.<ref name="Sacks">{{cite book |last=Sacks |first=Oliver |title=Hallucinations |year=2012 |publisher=Alfred A. Knopf |location=New York |isbn=978-0-307-95724-5 |edition=1st American}}</ref> However, the first scientific description of the disorder was reported in the early 1900s. In the last two decades, Berrios has reported case studies in 1990 and 1991 along with Keshavan et al. in 1992. Berrios concluded that confirmed diagnoses of deafness, ear disease, brain disease, advanced age and drug use are all important factors in the development of musical hallucinations. After analyzing 46 cases, Berrios found a female predominance of 80% in women over the age of 60. The study concluded that musical hallucinations were more likely to be seen in elderly women affected by deafness or brain disease than in individuals with no psychiatric illness at all.<ref name ="Berrios">{{cite journal |last=Berrios |first=GE |title=Musical hallucinations. A historical and clinical study |journal=British Journal of Psychiatry |year=1990 |volume=156 |issue=2 |pages=188–94 |pmid=2180526 |doi=10.1192/bjp.156.2.188}}</ref><ref name="Keshavan">{{cite journal |last=Keshavan |first=M.S. |author2=David, A.S. |author3=Steingard, S. |author4=Lishman, W.A. |title=Musical hallucinations: a review and synthesis |journal=Cognitive and Behavioral Neurology |year=1992 |volume=3 |issue=3 |pages=211–23}}</ref>
Keshevan and Berrios were the first authors to identify classes of musical hallucinations. These classes consisted of hearing loss, coarse brain disease (i.e. tumors), [[epilepsy|epileptic disorder]], [[stroke]], and psychiatric disorder. Although no statistical analyses were performed, the authors stated that deafness was the most strongly related factor in musical hallucinations and that there was a female predominance, which could entail a genetic component.<ref name="Evers" /><ref name="Berrios" /><ref name="Keshavan" />
== References == {{reflist|30em}}
{{Music psychology}}

{{notability|Places|date=May 2017}} {{Infobox museum | name = Osaka City Museum of Fine Arts | native_name = 大阪市立美術館 | native_name_lang = jpn | image = Keitakuen01s3000.jpg | imagesize = 200 | caption = Exterior of the museum | alt = Exterior of the Osaka City Museum of Fine Arts | map_type = Japan | map_size = 200 | map_caption = | coordinates = {{coord|34.650111|135.510528|type:landmark_region:JP|display=inline,title}} | established = {{Start date|1936|5|01}} | location = [[Osaka]], [[Japan]] | type = [[Art museum]] | collection_size = Over 8400 | visitors = | president = | curator = | owner = | publictransit = | car_park = | network = | website = {{homepage|www.osaka-art-museum.jp/en/}} }} The {{nihongo|'''Osaka City Museum of Fine Arts'''|大阪市立美術館}} is a museum located in [[Tennōji Park]], [[Tennōji-ku, Osaka|Tennōji-ku]], [[Osaka]], [[Japan]]. The museum focuses on Japanese and east Asian art.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://bunka.nii.ac.jp/museums/detail/454 |script-title=ja:大阪市立美術館 |trans-title=Osaka City Museum of Fine Arts |language=Japanese |publisher=[[Agency for Cultural Affairs]] |accessdate=21 May 2017}}</ref>
== Collection == === Important Cultural Properties === <gallery> File:Katsushika Hokusai - Shell Gathering - Google Art Project.jpg|[[Hokusai]], Shell Gathering, 19th century File:Mi Fu - Calligraphy in Grass Script - Google Art Project.jpg|[[Mi Fu]], Calligraphy in Grass Script, late 11th century File:Gong Suran - Ming Consort Leaving the Country - Google Art Project.jpg|Gong Suran, 12th-13th century </gallery>

{{Infobox video game |title=Panzer Tactics DS |image= Panzer Tactics DS Coverart.png |caption= |developer=[[Sproing Interactive Media]] |publisher= '''DS'''{{vgrelease|NA|[[Conspiracy Entertainment]]|EU|10tacle Studios}} '''Windows''', [[iOS]]{{vgrelease|WW|[[bitComposer Games]]}} |designer= |series= |engine= |released='''DS'''{{vgrelease|NA|November 7, [[2007 in video gaming|2007]] <ref>[http://games.ign.com/articles/833/833362p1.html "Panzer Tactics DS Invades Retailers"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120206173929/http://games.ign.com/articles/833/833362p1.html |date=2012-02-06 }} (IGN)</ref>|PAL|February 15, 2008}} '''Windows''', '''iOS'''{{vgrelease|WW|May 22, [[2014 in video gaming|2014]]}} |genre=[[Turn-based tactics]] |modes=[[Single player]], 1-4 Multiplayer |platforms=[[Nintendo DS]], [[Windows]] }}
'''''Panzer Tactics DS''''' is a [[turn-based tactical]] [[video game]] for the [[Nintendo DS]] developed by [[Sproing Interactive Media]]. It was released in North America on November 7, [[2007 in video gaming|2007]]. On March 6 [[2014 in video gaming|2014]], bitComposer Games announced Panzer Tactics HD, the official HD remake for PC and iPad.<ref>[http://bitcomposer.com/www_en/newsarchive.aspx?newsid=2f7ca0af-8e47-40cc-b6a8-e5d82ed10906 "bitComposer Games Announcement News"]</ref> The HD version was released on May 22, 2014.
==Gameplay== ''Panzer Tactics DS'' is set in [[World War II]]. The game includes three campaigns: [[Nazi Germany|German]], [[Russia]]n, and [[Allies of World War II|Allied]], with 10 missions plus one bonus mission each. In addition to single player, the DS version also has [[Nintendo Wi-fi Connection]], wireless, and [[Hotseat (multiplayer mode)|hotseat]] multiplayer.
Completing optional mission objectives unlocks bonus missions and other tactical enhancements. The game includes over 20 special attacks and 150 land, sea, and air units. There are 10 multiplayer maps of various sizes played over 14 different types of terrain. Different battle animations for all units and a wide range of special effects, explosions, and weather effects are displayed.
The Nintendo Wi-fi Connection and wireless multiplayer allow for up to four players per game, while hotseat mode allows two players on the same Nintendo DS. An online ladder system tracks high scores.
==Reception== {{Video game reviews | GameRev = B- | IGN = 6.0 }}
''Panzer Tactics DS'' received mixed reviews overall. IGN praised the single player campaigns, but criticized the multiplayer modes.<ref>[http://uk.ds.ign.com/articles/836/836662p1.html]</ref> Game Revolution also praised the single player mode, calling it a "deep, rewarding experience", while saying that the game had "awkward mutliplayer issues."<ref>[http://www.gamerevolution.com/review/ds/panzer_tactics]</ref> Review aggregator sites [[Metacritic]] and [[GameRankings]] rate ''Panzer Tactics DS'' at 67/100 and 70% respectively.<ref>[http://www.metacritic.com/games/platforms/ds/panzertacticsds?q=panzer%20tactics%20ds]</ref><ref>[http://www.gamerankings.com/htmlpages2/932721.asp]</ref>
==See also== * ''[[Panzer General]]'' * ''[[Panzer Tactics HD]]''
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.gamespot.com/ds/strategy/panzertactics/index.html ''Panzer Tactics DS''] at [[GameSpot]]
[[Category:2007 video games]] [[Category:Nintendo DS games]] [[Category:Nintendo Wi-Fi Connection games]] [[Category:Computer wargames]] [[Category:Turn-based tactics video games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Austria]] [[Category:Windows games]]

{{about|the publication named after the character|the character himself (in context as part of The Bash Street Kids)|Plug (The Bash Street Kids)}} {{italic title}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2017}} {{Use British English|date=March 2017}} '''''Plug''''' was a [[United Kingdom|British]] comics magazine that ran for 75 issues from 24 September 1977 until 24 February 1979, when it merged with ''[[The Beezer]]''. It was edited by [[Ian Gray (comics)|Ian Gray]].<ref name="guardian">[[Paul Gravett]], [https://www.theguardian.com/news/2007/sep/20/guardianobituaries.pressandpublishing "Obituary: Ian Gray"], ''[[The Guardian]]'', 20 September 2007</ref>
A [[Spin-off (media)|spin-off]] from ''[[The Bash Street Kids]]'' [[comic strip]] in ''[[The Beano]]'', the comic was based on the character ''Plug'' who was a distinctively ugly member of the Bash Street Kids. His dog (''Pug'') from [[Pup Parade]], and a new character called ''Chunkee the Monkey'' (Plug's pet monkey) accompanied him. [[Vic Neill]] mainly drew the title character's strip. The comic also had its own fan club, the ''Plug Sports and Social Club''. The comic was inspired in part by ''[[Mad Magazine]]''.
The ''Plug'' comic was never a big hit, possibly because, at 9 [[penny|pence]], it was too expensive{{inline-speculation|date=August 2015}} compared to other [[D. C. Thomson & Co. Ltd|D.C. Thomson]] comics at the time, which were priced at around 5 pence. According to the 2008 book ''The History of the Beano'', for a while there were rumours of a "curse of ''Plug''", fuelled by the fact that a number of celebrities featured in ''Mad'' magazine-style caricatures on the comic's cover died soon after, most notably [[John Wayne]]. However, the strip's use of gravure painting is still used in comics today.
==List of ''Plug'' comic strips==
{| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Strip Title ! Artist ! First Appearance <ref name =TUniverse>http://www.topper-universe.co.uk/plug/plug_summary.php?sort=1a</ref> ! Last Appearance <ref name = TUniverse/> ! Notes |- | Antchester United | [[John Geering]] | 1 | 75 | The adventures of an insect football team. Survived merger with the Beezer. |- |Ava Banana | | 1 | 18 |Ava was a female athlete "strong as an ox, gentle as a lamb". Her trainer was Charlton Veston, their names being plays on [[Ava Gardner]] and [[Charlton Heston]] |- |The Bandshees | | 1 | 42 |Creatures playing in a band, "''fresh from their successful tour of Mars''". Readers were invited to send in funny songs that they had written |- |Bedtime Story | | 36 | 50 | Text story |- |Crazy Horse - The Nutty Nag | | 19 | 75 |The adventures of a talking [[horse]] |- |Digby the Human Mole |[[Gordon Bell (artist)|Gordon Bell]] | 1 | 75 |A prisoner who constantly failed to escape from jail by digging tunnels. He had a huge mole-like nose and an enormous appetite. |- | Doctor Rotcod and Drib | | 44 | 75 | |- |D'ye Ken John Squeal and his Hopeless Hounds | | 44 | 75 |A daft celebration of fox hunting. Its title parodied [[D'ye ken John Peel#Lyrics of D.27ye ken John Peel|an 18th-century Scottish ballad]]. |- |Eddie Daring | | 27 | 43 |A boy obsessed with [[rugby league]], with Randolph, his pet [[rat]] (''The Original Dirty Rat''). His name was a play on [[Eddie Waring]], a popular TV sports commentator at the time. |- |Eebagoom | | 1 | 75 |The ancient British settlement of Liverpool invaded by Julius Sneezer and his Roman legions. Survived merger with the Beezer. |- |First Ada |Gordon Bell | 1 | 75 |Always willing to practice her first aid on any unsuspecting passer-by. Ada also had a [[St. Bernard (dog)|St. Bernard dog]] as her companion. Survived merger with the Beezer. |- |The Games Gang - They're Game for Everything. | | 1 | 43 |Starred Meltem John, Bee-Bop, Fuzz, Rocky, Modriel, Magnus Spike and Rollerball, a gang who invented games to play amongst themselves. (Meltem John and Magnus Spike are plays on [[Elton John]] and [[Magnus Pyke]].) |- |Gnoo Faces | | 1 | 25 |A strip about "''three screwball Gnoos, trying to break into showbiz!''" The judging panel was made up of Mickie Musk (the skunk), Lionel Bear, Arthur Aardvark and Tony Scratch (the tiger). The name was a play on [[New Faces]], a popular UK talent show at the time. |- |Gulp - The Galactic Goon with the GIGANTIC Gullet | | 58 | 75 | |- |Hugh's Zoo |Gordon Bell | 1 | 75 |The adventures of Hugh and his backyard menagerie. Survived merger with the Beezer. |- |The Invasion of the Plug Bugs | | 26 | 75 |A strip about a group of aliens |- |Jockey | |44 |75 |- |Lumpy Gibbon | | 1 | 25 |Starred Lumpy Gibbon (a huge gibbon), Colonel Podgy Whiner (a hunter), Little Gibbon and Man Eating Tiger Moth. The title was a homage to the 1975 song "[[Funky Gibbon]]", by [[The Goodies]] |- |Luncheon Vulture | | 26 | 57 |The adventures of a hungry [[vulture]]. The name echoes [[luncheon voucher]] |- |The Nutcase Bookcase - Guidebooks for Goons | | 19 | 75 |Plug would star in a 'guide' to doing something, usually with disastrous results |- |Plug | | 1 | 75 | Survived merger with the Beezer. |- |Sea Urchin | | 1 | 18 |An amphibious boy who had underwater adventures with his friend Roger, the flying fish. The main antagonist of the strip was Silas Sharke, the underwater rotter |- |Supporting Life |[[Bill Ritchie]] | 1 | 43 |Starred Elvis, Plug's little brother, looking at a different football team each week. The first was [[Arsenal F.C.]]. |- |Tony Jackpot |[[John Dallas (comics)|John Dallas]] | 1 | 74 |A boy obsessed with [[golf]], whose name was a play on that of British golfer (and 1969 British Open winner), [[Tony Jacklin]]. |- |Violent Elizabeth | | 44 | 75 | Her name was a play on Violet Elizabeth Bott, a well-known character from the [[Just William]] books by [[Richmal Crompton]]. |}
