revision.text:
{{Infobox video game | title = The Cliffhanger: Edward Randy | image = [[Image:Edward randy arcadeflyer.png|224px|Japanese arcade flyer of The Cliffhanger: Edward Randy.]] | caption = Japanese arcade flyer of ''The Cliffhanger: Edward Randy''. | developer = [[Data East]] | publisher = [[Data East]] | designer = | composer = Akira Takemoto
Tatsuya Kiuchi
Tomoyoshi Sato |released = {{vgrelease|JP|1990}} | genre = [[Action-adventure game]] | modes = 1-2 players ([[cooperative gameplay|Cooperative]]) | cabinet = Upright | arcade system = | display = [[Raster graphics|Raster]], Horizontal Standard Resolution | platforms = [[Arcade game|Arcade]] }} '''''The Cliffhanger: Edward Randy''''', known in [[Japan]] simply as {{nihongo|'''''Edward Randy'''''|エドワードランディ|edowādo randi}}, is a side-scrolling [[Action-adventure game|action-adventure]] [[arcade game]] released in [[Japan]] by [[Data East]] in [[1990 in video gaming|1990]]. ==History== The game is set in a [[steampunk]] (or, rather, [[dieselpunk]]) worldview, where many scenes and settings are directly modeled after ''[[Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade]]'', including a whip-wielding main character, [[Nazi Germany|Nazi]]-like enemy army, and battles that take place on [[biplanes]], as well as boats in a [[Venice]]-like location. The game also contains parodies or homages to works by [[Hayao Miyazaki]] and [[Buster Keaton]]. The game also uses a movie-like effect where upcoming in-game events are previewed in the game's background. ==In-game description== ===Plot=== The game takes place during the 1930s in an unspecified European country. Research on a secret weapon of mass destruction was being conducted in this country under the leadership of a fearsome army general, the ''Dark Ogre'', but an elderly scientist decides to escape after learning that he was being manipulated by the general. The scientist gives the key piece of his research, a prism stone, to his granddaughter ''Charlotte'' as he escapes, and the general pursues the prism with the full force of his army. Charlotte takes refuge in the home of ''Edward Randy'', a teenage boy who was preparing for his first date in half a year with his girlfriend, ''Jennifer'', while Edward suddenly finds himself in the midst of a huge adventure involving a dangerous plan to destroy the world. ===Gameplay=== [[Image:Thecliffhanger edwardrandy screenshot.png|left|thumb|Screenshot of ''The Cliffhanger: Edward Randy''.]] The player controls the main character using an 8-way joystick and 2 buttons, one for attacking and one for jumping. The main character attacks using a whip, and he can attack in 8 different directions depending on the direction pressed on the joystick. He can also slide on the ground when the jump button is pressed while the joystick is pressed to the side or diagonally downwards. Pressing the joystick diagonally upwards causes the character to run quickly, and pressing down on the joystick while the character is in the air allows him to stomp on enemies on the ground. The character can also do a spin-attack by looping their whip on other objects and holding left or right on the joystick. The character is invincible while they are spinning, but can only spin 4 times per attack. The game is completed when the player finishes all 7 levels, and up to 2 players can play together at a time. There are no lives in the game, and the main character's remaining health is directly linked to the number of points gained by the player on each level. The player can revive the main character's health by killing more enemies, and they lose points along with health when they are hit by enemy attacks. The player is taken to the game over screen when their points (health) reaches 0. Therefore, the high score is calculated as the highest number of points the player had at any point in the game rather than the number of points they have at the end of the game. The game's story-line is explained in demo screens that appear in-between levels. The level's subtitle is displayed before the start of each level. ==External links== *[http://www.mameworld.net/maws/romset/edrandy ''The Cliffhanger: Edward Randy'' at MameWorld.Net] *[http://www.arcade-history.com/index.php?page=detail&id=475 ''The Cliffhanger: Edward Randy'' at arcade-history.com] *{{KLOV game|id=7691}} *''[http://www.hardcoregaming101.net/edrandy/edrandy.htm The Cliffhanger: Edward Randy]'' at [http://www.hardcoregaming101.net/edrandy/edrandy.htm Hardcore Gaming 101] {{DEFAULTSORT:Cliffhanger: Edward Randy, The}} [[Category:1990 video games]] [[Category:Arcade games]] [[Category:Arcade-only games]] [[Category:Action video games]] [[Category:Cooperative video games]] [[Category:Data East video games]] [[Category:Japan-exclusive video games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Japan]]

revision.comment: /* Synopsis */
revision.text:
{{for|the film based on the book|The Disaster Artist (film)}} {{Infobox book | name = The Disaster Artist | image = The_Disaster_Artist.jpg | caption = Front cover of first edition | alt = Cover of first edition book with image of film reel to look like a round bomb with a lit fuse. | author = [[Greg Sestero]]
[[Tom Bissell]] | country = United States | language = English | genre = [[Non-fiction]], [[memoir]]s | publisher = [[Simon & Schuster]] | release_date = {{Date|October 10, 2013|mdy}} | media_type = Print ([[hardcover]] and [[paperback]]), [[e-book]], [[Audiobook]] | pages = 268 pp | isbn = 1451661193 | isbn_note = (hardback edition) | congress = 2013008798 | oclc = 830352130 | website = {{Official URL}} }} '''''The Disaster Artist: My Life Inside The Room, the Greatest Bad Movie Ever Made''''' is a 2013 [[non-fiction]] book written by [[Greg Sestero]] and [[Tom Bissell]]. Sestero details the troubled development and production of the 2003 cult film ''[[The Room (film)|The Room]],'' his own struggles as a young actor, and his relationship with ''Room'' director [[Tommy Wiseau]].{{cite news|last1=Ruland|first1=Jim|url=http://www.latimes.com/books/jacketcopy/la-ca-jc-greg-sestero-tom-bissell-20130929-story.html|title=Worst movie ever? 'The Disaster Artist' explores 'The Room'|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|accessdate=October 12, 2017|date=September 27, 2013}} In December 2017, a [[The Disaster Artist (film)|film adaptation of the same name]] was released, directed and produced by and starring [[James Franco]] as Wiseau, with his brother and co-producer [[Dave Franco]] in the role of Sestero. ==Synopsis== Sestero, an aspiring actor struggling with confidence, first encounters Wiseau in an acting class. Sestero is at first perplexed by Wiseau's over-the-top acting technique, his unusual physical appearance, his unidentifiable accent and his eccentric behavior, which includes a fascination with all things American and a refusal to discuss his past. At the same time, Sestero admires Wiseau's boldness and his genuine enthusiasm for both life and acting. The two form an odd but affectionate bond as Sestero begins to learn of the many contradictions of Wiseau's personality. As Sestero slowly accrues more acting credits and makes other friends, Wiseau grows jealous and schemes to earn similar acknowledgement (such as earning a [[SAG card]] by producing and starring in a commercial for a company he himself owned), leading Sestero to become uncomfortable with their relationship. After viewing ''[[The Talented Mr. Ripley (film)|The Talented Mr. Ripley]]'' for the first time, Sestero is struck by how similar Wiseau is to the title character and convinces him to see the film. However, instead of recognizing his own behavior, Wiseau is deeply impressed by the performance and becomes obsessed with creating a movie just as emotionally powerful. The result is the screenplay for ''[[The Room (film)|The Room]]'', which includes a character, Mark, named after actor [[Matt Damon]] (whose name Wiseau had misheard). Backed by a seemingly endless, mysterious supply of money, Wiseau develops, produces, directs and stars in ''[[The Room (film)|The Room]]'', despite having no knowledge of filmmaking. On-set relationships are a disaster: the story itself is nonsensical and full of plot threads that are never addressed or resolved (a matter complicated by Wiseau refusing to give anyone a full copy of the script); Wiseau's camera set-up requires two full crews to operate, actors and crew storm off the set, scripts are rewritten in the middle of scenes, sets are broken down only to be rebuilt and re-shot the following day, and at the last possible moment, Wiseau convinces Sestero to join the crew as one of the principal actors, in spite of the role already having been cast. By the end of shooting, the cast and crew, convinced that the film will never be seen, lose their enthusiasm, resulting in lackluster performances and technical blunders that are never corrected. Sestero screens a rough cut of the film for his friends and family, who are enthralled by its bizarre ineptitude. Their reaction turns out to be prophetic when, eight months later, Wiseau secures a release for the film, beginning its cult reputation as "the ''[[Citizen Kane]]'' of [[list of films considered the worst|bad movies]]". The book ends with Sestero's meditation on the power—and danger—of unconditional belief in one's dreams. ==Film adaptation== {{Main|The Disaster Artist (film)}} A film adaptation [[The Disaster Artist (film)|of the same name]], directed and co-produced by and starring [[James Franco]] as Wiseau and [[Dave Franco]] as Sestero, premiered at [[South by Southwest]] on March 12, 2017, and was released in the United States on December 1, 2017. ==Audiobook== In May 2014, an [[audiobook]] version of ''The Disaster Artist'' was released by [[Tantor Audio]], with Sestero reading the story. Sestero's impression of Wiseau in the audiobook has received praise from critics, including ''[[The Huffington Post]]'' and [[Publishers Weekly]].{{cite web|last1=Hartsell|first1=Carol|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/05/27/greg-sestero-tommy-wiseau-impression_n_5399103.html|title=Listen To Greg Sestero's Awesome Tommy Wiseau Impression In This 'Disaster Artist' Audioclip|work=[[HuffPost]]|accessdate=December 6, 2015|date=May 27, 2014}} ''The Disaster Artist'' audiobook was named a finalist for the 2015 [[Audie Awards]] for Best Humor Audiobook.{{cite web|title=20th Annual Audie finalists announced in thirty categories|url=https://www.audiopub.org/uploads/pdf/2015_Audie_Awards_Release.pdf|publisher=[[Audio Publishers Association]]|accessdate=October 12, 2017|date=February 11, 2015}} ==Awards== In March 2014, ''The Disaster Artist'' (Audiobook) won for ''Favorite Non-Fiction Book of 2013'' at [[Bookish]].{{cite web|last1=Gallucci|first1=Kelly|title=Oscar-Style Nominations For Our Favorite Books of 2013|url=https://www.bookish.com/articles/oscar-style-nominations-for-our-favorite-books-of-2013/|publisher=[[Bookish]]|accessdate=October 12, 2017|date=March 3, 2014}} On November 23, 2014, ''The Disaster Artist'' won for Best Non-Fiction at the National Arts & Entertainment Journalism Awards ceremony in Los Angeles. The judges praised the book, stating "''The Disaster Artist'' is not only a hell of a good read, it will make a great film if ever adapted. It's equal parts ''[[Ed Wood (film)|Ed Wood]]'', ''[[American Hustle]]'' and demented ''[[Citizen Kane]]''—with a dash of [[Monty Python]] thrown into the mix".{{cite web|title=2014 Winners - 7th National Arts & Entertainment Journalism Awards|url=http://lapressclub.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/2014-National-Arts-Entertainment-Journalism-Award-Winners.pdf|publisher=[[Los Angeles Press Club]]|accessdate=October 12, 2017|date=2014}} On February 11, 2015, ''The Disaster Artist'' (Audiobook) was nominated for Best Humor Audiobook at the [[Audie Award]]s, and was narrated by author [[Greg Sestero]]. The awards ceremony was held May 28, 2015 in New York City. On January 23, 2018 ''The Disaster Artist'' was nominated for [[Best Adapted Screenplay]] at the 90th Oscars. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official website}} * [http://www.tantor.com/BookDetail.asp?Product=F0152_DisasterArtist "Audiobook"] {{DEFAULTSORT:Disaster Artist, The}} [[Category:2013 non-fiction books]] [[Category:Books about film]] [[Category:Books adapted into films]] [[Category:Simon & Schuster books]] [[Category:Show business memoirs]]

revision.comment: /* Winners */
revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=July 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2016}} The '''World Trophy''', originally known as the '''Helms Award''', was an annual sporting award established by the [[Helms Athletic Foundation]] in 1939 to honour the foremost amateur athlete of each continent of the world, including Africa, Asia, Australasia, Europe, North America, and South America.<ref name=olympic>{{cite journal|title=Helms Athletic Foundation|url=http://library.la84.org/OlympicInformationCenter/OlympicReview/1951/BDCE25/BDCE25n.pdf|journal=Bulletin du Comite International Olympique|date=1951|issue= 25|pages=26–28}}</ref> Even though the Foundation was established in 1936, the awards date back to the 1896, the year of the first [[Summer Olympics]]. Australasian awards for 1896 to 1949 were decided by a Committee in [[Australasia]] established by the Foundation. Members of the Committee were [[Frank Beaurepaire|Sir Frank Beaurepaire]] (Chairman), and Messrs. [[Harold Alderson|Harold G. Alderson]], [[Hugh Weir|Hugh R. Weir]], [[Jack Metcalfe]], Frank H. Pizzey, [[Hector de Lacy]], [[Ern Cowley]] and R.J. McPherson (Secretary). <ref name=advertiser>{{cite news|title=World of Sport|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article44937936|accessdate=5 February 2015|work=Adelaide Advertiser|date=25 August 1950}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=de Lacy|first1=H.A.|title=HELMS AWARD – Sedgman was clear winner|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article178169277|accessdate=9 June 2015|work=Sporting Globe|date=9 January 1952}}</ref> After the initial Committee selection, amateur athletes were nominated by their own countries for consideration by the Foundation. Winners were presented with a silver plaque and had their names added to the World Trophy that was located at the Helms Foundation and subsequently the Amateur Athletic Foundation of Los Angeles (now known as the [[LA84 Foundation]]).<ref name=pollard/> Winners can only win the award once.<ref name=pollard/>

revision.comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/107.219.122.27|107.219.122.27]] ([[User talk:107.219.122.27|talk]]) to last revision by 2602:306:CF32:5BD0:E5B1:C383:A17A:CDAB. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=July 2010}} [[File:Hemlock Overlook - Zip-line - 04.jpg|thumb|Zip-line in [[Hemlock Overlook Regional Park|Hemlock Overlook]] [[rope course]].]] [[File:Zip-line over rainforest canopy 4 January 2005, Costa Rica.jpg|right|thumb|Zip-lining in [[Costa Rica]]]]
A '''zip-line''' (or '''zip line''', '''zipline''', '''Sypline''', '''zip wire''', '''aerial runway''', '''aerial ropeslide''', '''death slide''', '''flying fox''', or, in South Africa, '''foefie slide''')<ref>''Who Really Benefits from Tourism'', Publ. Equations, Karnataka, India, 2010. Working Papers Series. "Canopy Tourism", [https://books.google.com/books?id=yZ3JA4Jm-oMC&lpg=PA37&dq=Zip-line%20%22flying%20fox%22%20%22aerial%20runway%22&pg=PA37#v=onepage&q=Zip-line&f=false page 37]</ref><ref>Jacques Marais, Lisa De Speville, ''Adventure Racing'', Publisher Human Kinetics, 2004, {{ISBN|0736059113}}, 9780736059114, 160 pages, [https://books.google.com/books?id=47okqR2JA-QC&lpg=PA156&dq=Zip-line%20%22flying%20fox%22%20%22tyrolean%22&pg=PA156#v=onepage&q=Zip-line%20%22flying%20fox%22%20%22tyrolean%22&f=false page 156]</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://equitabletourism.org/readfull.php?AID=1402|title=Equitable Tourism Options (EQUATIONS) - Working Paper Series 2009-10|author=|date=|website=equitabletourism.org|accessdate=1 May 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.collinsdictionary.com/dictionary/english/foefie-slide|title=Foefie slide definition and meaning - Collins English Dictionary|author=|date=|website=www.collinsdictionary.com|accessdate=1 May 2018}}</ref> consists of a [[pulley]] suspended on a [[Wire rope|cable]], usually made of stainless steel, mounted on a [[slope]]. It is designed to enable a user propelled by [[gravity]] to travel from the top to the bottom of the inclined cable by holding on to, or attaching to, the freely moving pulley. Zip-lines come in many forms, most often used as a means of entertainment. They may be short and low, intended for child's play and found on some [[playground]]s. Longer and higher rides are often used as a means of accessing remote areas, such as a [[rainforest]] [[Canopy (forest)|canopy]]. Zip line tours are becoming popular vacation activities, which are found at outdoor adventure camps or upscale resorts, where they may be an element on a larger challenge or [[ropes course]].<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.mauimagazine.net/Maui-Magazine/September-October-2008/Dont-Look-Down/|title=Don't Look Down!|last=Thayer|first=Matthew|date=September–October 2008|magazine=Maui No Ka ‘Oi magazine|accessdate=9 March 2011|location=Maui, Hawaii|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101126151202/http://www.mauimagazine.net/Maui-Magazine/September-October-2008/Dont-Look-Down/|archivedate=26 November 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The jungles of [[Costa Rica]], [[Florida]], [[Puerto Vallarta]], and [[Nicaragua]] are popular destinations for zip line enthusiasts.
==History== The zip-wire has been used as a transportation method in some mountainous countries for many years.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lowtechmagazine.com/2011/01/aerial-ropeways-automatic-cargo-transport.html|title=Aerial ropeways: automatic cargo transport for a bargain|publisher=LOW-TECH MAGAZINE, Doubts on progress and technology|accessdate=28 August 2014}}</ref> In some remote areas in China such as [[Salween River|Nujiang (Salween)]] valley in [[Yunnan]], zip lines served the purposes of bridges across rivers, but due to a poor safety record, they have mostly been replaced by real bridges by 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gokunming.com/en/blog/item/3444/bye_bye_nujiang_ziplines|title=Bye-bye Nujiang ziplines|publisher=GoKunming|accessdate=2 December 2015}}</ref> Referred to as "an inclined strong",<ref>See the second paragraph here [http://www.enotes.com/invisible-man-wells-text/chapter-x-mr-marvels-visit-to-iping] where the phrase is underlined.</ref> one appears in ''[[The Invisible Man]]'' by [[H. G. Wells]], published in 1897, as part of a Whit-Monday fair.
In 1739, [[Robert Cadman]], a [[steeplejack]] and [[Tightrope walking|ropeslider]], died when descending from [[Shrewsbury|Shrewsbury's]] [[St Mary's Church, Shrewsbury|St Mary’s Church]] when his rope snapped.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=pis&GRid=3976&PIgrid=3976&PIcrid=638945&PIpi=78262&|title=Find A Grave - Millions of Cemetery Records|author=|date=|website=www.findagrave.com|accessdate=1 May 2018}}</ref>
[[Alberto Santos-Dumont]] used a direct ancestor of the zip-line in spring 1906 for a method of testing various characteristics of his [[Santos-Dumont 14-bis]] [[Aviation in the pioneer era|pioneer era]] [[Canard (aeronautics)|canard]] biplane, before it ever flew under its own power later that year.{{citation needed|date=March 2013}}
In the Australian [[outback]], zip-lines were occasionally used for delivering food, cigarettes or tools to people working on the other side of an obstacle such as a gully or river. Australian troops have used them to deliver food, mail and even ammunition to forward positions in several conflicts.{{citation needed|date=March 2013}}
==Flying fox== {{main|Flying fox (cablecar)}} [[File:Hocking Peaks Adventure Park, Logan, Ohio.jpg|thumb|Hocking Peaks Adventure Park, [[Logan, Ohio]]]] [[File:Zip line in Costa Rica.JPG|right|thumb|upright|Zip-line set-up in Costa Rica]] The term "flying fox" is most commonly used in reference to a small-scale zip line typically used as an item of [[child]]ren's [[Play (activity)|play]] equipment, except in [[Australia]] and [[New Zealand]] where it also refers to professional forms of zip-line equipment.<ref>{{cite web| url= http://www.ziplinerider.com/Australia_Ziplines.html |title=Zip Lines, Flying Fox in Australia|publisher=Ziplinerider.com|accessdate=9 August 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ziplinerider.com/New_Zealand_Ziplines.html |title=Zip Lines, Flying Fox in New Zealand|publisher=Ziplinerider.com|accessdate=9 August 2012|deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120606014427/http://www.ziplinerider.com/New_Zealand_Ziplines.html |archivedate=6 June 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
With the flying fox, the [[Pulley|pulley(s)]], attached to the car, are fixed to the cable. The car itself can consist of anything from a simple hand grip, with the user hanging underneath, to a bucket for transporting small items, to a quite elaborate construction, perhaps including a seat or a safety strap. Children's versions are usually not set up with a steep incline, so the speeds are kept relatively low, negating the need for a means of stopping.
To be propelled by gravity, the cable needs to be on a fairly steep slope. Even then the car will generally not travel completely to the end (although this will depend on the [[Structural load|load]]), and some means of safely stopping the car at the bottom end is sometimes needed. It can be returned by several means, either by simply pushing the car back to the top of the hill on foot (as is common in children's play equipment as they do not hang far from the ground) or a line leading from the car to the uphill end.
The flying fox is usually made with rope instead of steel cable to make it easier and cheaper to install, uninstall and transport. Riders on the Flying Fox need [[safety harness]] to get support on the zip line.
==Professional courses== Professional versions of a zip-line are most typically used as an outdoor adventure activity. In contrast to "flying foxes" professional courses are usually operated at higher speeds, covering much longer distances and sometimes at considerable heights. The users are physically attached to the cable by a [[safety harness|harness]] that attaches to a removable [[zip line trolley|trolley]]. A [[helmet]] is required on almost all courses of any size.
Cables can be very high, starting at a height of over {{convert|9|m|abbr=on}}, and traveling well over {{convert|460|m|abbr=on}}. All zip-line cables have some degree of sag. The proper tensioning of a cable is important and allows the ability to tune the ride of a zip line.
Zip lines are a common way to return participants to the ground at the end of a ropes adventure course.
[[File:Zip line spring braking system.jpg|thumb|Zip-line spring braking system]]
=== Braking ===
Users of zip-lines must have means of stopping themselves. Typical mechanisms include:<ref>{{cite web|last1=Roper|first1=Aaron|title=Zip Line Braking Methods|url=http://help.ziplinegear.com/entries/22964583-Zip-Line-Braking-Methods|website=ZipLineGear Knowledge Base|accessdate=2 February 2015}}</ref> * Friction created between the pulley against the cable. * Thick, purpose-built leather gloves. * A mat or netting at the lower end of the incline. * A passive arrester system composed of [[spring (device)|springs]], pulleys, [[counterweight]]s, [[bungee cord]], [[tire]] or other devices, which slows and then stops the trolley's motion. * A "capture block" which is a block on the cable that is tethered to a rope controlled by a staff who can manually apply friction on the rope to slow the user down. * Gravity stop, exploiting the sag in the cable. The belly of the cable is always lower than the termination point. The amount of incline on a zip line controls the speed at which the user arrives at the termination point. * Hand brake at the end of the zip line.
=== Safety ===
With proper knowledge and training on the part of the operators, along with good maintenance, zip lines are generally safe and easy to use. In 2012 there were an estimated 200 commercial zip lines in the US and a further 13,000 private ones resulting in 3,600 visits to the emergency room.<ref>{{cite news|title=Zipline-related injuries are rapidly increasing|url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2015/10/151005080118.htm|accessdate=7 October 2015|work=[[Science Daily]]|date=5 October 2015}}</ref>
==Records== The world's longest zip-line as of January 2018 is the 2.8 kilometer 'Jebel Jais Flight' at [[Jebel Jais]] in [[Ras Al Khaimah]], [[United Arab Emirates]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-emirates-attraction-zipline/uae-claims-worlds-longest-zipline-idUSKBN1FL50Z|title=UAE claims world's longest zipline |first=Rosanna|last=Lockwood|date=|website=reuters.com|accessdate=1 May 2018}}</ref>
"Parque de Aventura Barrancas del Cobre" at 2545 m (8,350 ft) in [[Copper Canyon]], Mexico was once the longest.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ziprider.com/rides/coppercanyon/ |title=Copper Canyon, Mexico Ziprider |publisher=Ziprider.com |date= |accessdate=29 December 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151229130707/http://ziprider.com/rides/coppercanyon/ |archivedate=29 December 2015 |df=dmy-all }}, http://parktropa.com/our-works-en/zipline/</ref>
In 2012, ZipFlyer Nepal (HighGround Adventures) was the world's steepest with max incline of 56%, is currently second in the world and is still the tallest zip line. It had a vertical drop of {{convert|610|m|ft|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://highgroundnepal.com/ |title=HGnepal Website |accessdate=4 July 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120709050527/http://www.highgroundnepal.com/|archivedate=9 July 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ziplinerider.com/Longest_Ziplines.html|title=Longest Zip Lines |publisher=ziplinerider.com |access-date=17 April 2012 |deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120430102750/http://www.ziplinerider.com/Longest_Ziplines.html|archivedate=30 April 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
On 19 September 2015 the world's steepest zipline was opened at [[Letalnica bratov Gorišek]], on the ski flying hill in [[Planica]], [[Slovenia]]. It is {{convert|566|m|ft}} long with a {{convert|202|m|ft}} vertical drop. It has an average 38.33% and a maximum 58.6% incline.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nc-planica.si/2015/09/18/postani-planiski-junak/ |title=Become hero of Planica|accessdate=18 September 2015}}</ref> The longest zipline in Europe, at just over 1600 meters long, is the Zip World Bethesda line in [[Penrhyn Quarry|Penryn Quarry]], [[Bethesda, Gwynedd|Bethesda]], Wales. The Zip World Bethesda line also holds the record for being the fastest Zip-Line in the world. <ref> {{cite web |url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/men/active/10752334/The-100mph-slide-riding-Europes-longest-zipline.html |title=The 100 MPH slide; Riding Europe's Longest Zipline|accessdate=3 July 2016}}</ref><ref> {{cite web|url=http://www.zipworld.co.uk/adventure/detail/velocity|title=Zip World Velocity|accessdate=3 July 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160815194521/http://www.zipworld.co.uk/adventure/detail/velocity|archivedate=15 August 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
The longest zipline in [[England]] is the Skywire<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://hanglooseadventure.com/skywire/|title=One of the best things to do in Cornwall {{!}} SkyWire Zip Wire|website=hanglooseadventure.com|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-06-15}}</ref> at the [[Eden Project]] in [[Cornwall]] measuring 660 meters (2,165 ft).
==Zip-line trolley== [[File:Departure zip SuperFly in Whistler, BC, Canada.jpg|thumb|Departure zip SuperFly in Whistler, BC, Canada]]
The zip-line trolley is the frame or assembly together with the pulley(s) also known as sheave(s) inside that run along the cable. (The term "trolley" is more often used when this assembly consists of more than a single pulley with simple hanger and bearing.) Often more than one pulley is used to spread the load over more than one spot on the cable, to reduce cable bending stresses that may lead to metal fatigue and cable breakage. This also reduces any tendency of a pulley to twist sideways and run off the cable, with disastrous results. In addition, the trolley is usually shaped with guards to hold the cable in the groove(s) of the pulley(s).
A pivoting link, such as a [[carabiner]], is used to secure the load to the trolley so that the trolley does not have a tendency to rock and thus fall off the cable if the load should sway. Load carriers ranging from enclosed cabins to gondolas to harnesses are attached to the link. Occasionally the load carrier is just a handhold or handlebar, although there is the danger of the rider losing his grip and falling. Such a simple carrier should be used only on zip lines that are near the ground or over water. The rider losing his grip due to the use of the simple carrier has led to a number of deaths.{{citation needed|date=August 2013}}
==Transportation== [[Yungas#Human use|Yungas]], [[Bolivia]], features a system of zip lines used for transporting harvested crops.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/programmes/2011/05/20115811409577464.html|title=The flying men of Yungas Valley|author=|date=|website=www.aljazeera.com|accessdate=1 May 2018}}</ref>

revision.comment: /* External links */
revision.text:
{{use mdy dates|date=March 2016}} {{Infobox film | name = Zorns Lemma | image = Zorns Lemma title screen.png | caption = Title screen | director = [[Hollis Frampton]] | producer = | writer = | starring = {{plainlist| *[[Joyce Wieland]] *Robert Huot *Marcia Steinbrecher<ref>MacDonald 1993, p. 70.</ref>}} | cinematography = | editing = | distributor = | released = {{Film date|1970}} | runtime = 60 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = }} '''''Zorns Lemma''''' is a 1970 American [[structural film|structural]] [[experimental film]] by [[Hollis Frampton]]. Originally starting as a series of photographs, the [[non-narrative film]] is structured around a 24-letter [[Latin alphabet]]. It remains, along with [[Michael Snow]]'s ''[[Wavelength (1967 film)|Wavelength]]'' and [[Tony Conrad]]'s ''[[The Flicker]]'', one of the best known examples of structural filmmaking.
==Content== The opening section of ''Zorns Lemma'' is 5 minutes long. In it a woman reads an [[abecedary]] of 24 couplets from ''The Bay State Primer'', an eighteenth century book designed to teach children the alphabet.<ref name="gidal-october">{{cite journal |last=Gidal |first=Peter |year=1985 |title=Interview with Hollis Frampton |journal=[[October (journal)|October]] |issue=32 |pages=93–117}}</ref> The film is entirely black during this section.
[[File:Zorns Lemma letter A.png|thumb|left|A letter ''A'' stamped on tin foil, the first of 24 such letters shown at the beginning of the second section]] The film's main section is silent and lasts 45 minutes, broken into 2,700 one-second units. It shows the viewer an evolving 24-part "alphabet". The section begins by presenting each letter typed on a sheet of tin foil.<ref name="gidal-october"/> The alphabet is initially composed of words that appear on street signs, photographed in [[Manhattan]]. As the film continues to cycle through the alphabet, individual letters are slowly substituted with images. The first four substitutions—fire (''x''), waves (''z''), smoke (''q''), and reeds (''y'')–depict the four [[classical elements]].<ref>{{cite journal |last=Weiss |first=Allen S. |year=1985 |title=Frampton's Lemma, Zorn's Dilemma |journal=[[October (journal)|October]] |issue=32 |pages=125–126}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last=Bershen |first=Wanda |date=September 1971 |title='Zorns Lemma' |journal=[[Artforum]] |page=44}}</ref>
The film's conclusion lasts 10 minutes. It shows a man, woman and dog walking through snow. During this scene, six women's voices alternate in reading the words of a passage from ''[[On Light, or the Ingression of Forms]]'' by [[Robert Grosseteste]].<ref name="gidal-october"/> The voices read at a rate of one word per second.<ref>Sitney 2002, p. 369.</ref>
==Production== ''Zorns Lemma'' emerged from ''Word Pictures'', a photography project that Frampton made from 1962 to 1963.<ref name="phillips-october">{{cite journal |last=Phillips |first=Christopher |year=1985 |title=Word Pictures: Frampton and Photography |journal=[[October (journal)|October]] |issue=32 |pages=62–76}}</ref> For ''Word Pictures'', Frampton shot over 2000 black-and-white [[35 mm format|35mm]] photographs of environmental words, seeking to explore the illusions of photography as a medium.<ref name="gidal-october"/> However, he had difficulty devising a form in which to present the photographs. During this period, Frampton became less active as a photographer and first started to experiment with filmmaking.<ref name="phillips-october"/> He started to make a film by shooting the photographs on a stand but thought the result looked "dead", deciding that he should film the words in color.<ref name="frampton-criterion">{{cite AV media |people=[[Hollis Frampton|Frampton, Hollis]] |year=2012 |section=Remarks by Frampton |title=A Hollis Frampton Odyssey |medium=DVD |publisher=[[The Criterion Collection]] }}</ref> He began filming static shots of words, carefully framing them with the use of a [[tripod (photography)|tripod]].<ref>{{cite journal |last=Zryd |first=Michael |year=2004 |title=History and Ambivalence in Hollis Frampton's ''Magellan'' |journal=[[October (journal)|October]] |issue=109 |page=139}}</ref>
Frampton thought that imposing his own order on the film would make it too similar to a poem, so he decided to use alphabetical order and avoid any conscious connections between words. Because the number of times he had captured each letter varied greatly, he decided to use the "double alphabet" and continuously cycle through the letters.<ref name="frampton-criterion"/> This structure left "holes" to be filled in the film.<ref name="frampton-criterion"/> Frampton decided to gradually substitute out the letters for images, originally planning to use entirely different images each time.<ref name="gidal-october"/> Frampton's production notes outline three criteria for selecting the images used. He preferred banal images, with the exception of animals included for "shock value". He preferred "sculptural" images showing work or the "illusion of space or substance". These included painting a wall (''k'') and changing a tire (''t''). Frampton worked in "cinematic or para-cinematic reference", often subtly so. The letter ''d'' is substituted with cookie dough being sliced with a star-shaped cookie cutter, as a cinematic reference to film "stars". Modular actions—such as a child swinging (''l'') or assembling [[Tinkertoy]]s (''r'')—serve as para-cinematic references to modular time.<ref>MacDonald 1995, pp. 61–66.</ref> Frampton set the length of each shot to be one second, or 24 frames. However, 24 of the shots have slight irregularities in their lengths. Frampton instructed [[key grip]] David Hamilton that 12 shots should have 23 frames and 12 shots should have 25 frames.<ref>Frampton 2009, p. 198.</ref>
The final section of ''Zorns Lemma'' was shot in 1970.<ref name=frampton76>Frampton 1976, p. 76.</ref> Frampton envisioned it as a time for the audience "to empty the mind".<ref name="frampton-criterion"/> When loading and unloading the film rolls, he intentionally exposed them to sunlight and created reel-end flares to emphasize "the materiality of film".<ref name=frampton76/>
Frampton's films are often titled after specialized scientific disciplines, as in the case of ''Maxwell's Demon'', ''Prince Rupert's Drops'', and ''Hapax Legomena''.<ref>Sitney 2002, pp. 369–370.</ref> In the early 1960s minimalist artist [[Carl Andre]] described to Frampton the [[Dedekind cut]], which partitions a totally ordered set into a set with no [[maximal element]] and a set with no minimal element.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Ragona |first=Melissa |year=2004 |title=Hidden Noise: Strategies of Sound Montage in the Future of Hollis Frampton |journal=[[October (journal)|October]] |issue=109 |pages=96–118}}</ref> He became interested in the relationship between [[set theory]] and film while working on his ongoing project ''Magellan''. Frampton titled ''Zorns Lemma'' after [[Zorn's lemma]] (also known as the Kuratowski–Zorn lemma), a proposition of set theory formulated by mathematician [[Max Zorn]] in 1935. Zorn's lemma describes [[partially ordered set]]s where every [[totally ordered]] subset has an upper bound. The letters and images in ''Zorns Lemma'' are sets whose order is discovered during the course of the film.<ref>Sitney 2002, pp. 369.</ref>
==Release and legacy== ''Zorns Lemma'' premiered at the [[David Geffen Hall|Philharmonic Hall]] for the 1970 [[New York Film Festival]].<ref>{{cite journal |last=Rosenbaum |first=Jonathan |authorlink=Jonathan Rosenbaum |year=2012 |title=Global Discoveries on DVD: Sometimes (Matters Arising) |url=http://cinema-scope.com/columns/global-discoveries-dvd-sometimes-matters-arising/ |journal=Cinema Scope |issue=51 |access-date=February 9, 2016}}</ref><ref name="thompson-nyt">{{cite news |last=Thompson |first=Howard |authorlink=Howard Thompson (film critic) |title=Double Pisces Scorpio Rising (1970) |url=https://www.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=9403E0DB1038EE34BC4C52DFBF66838B669EDE |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=September 14, 1970 |page=48 |access-date=February 9, 2016 }}</ref> It was the first experimental feature film to be screened there.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Atkinson |first=Michael |authorlink=Michael Atkinson (writer) |date=October 2012 |title=A Hollis Frampton Odyssey |journal=[[Sight & Sound]] |volume=22 |issue=10 |page=115}}</ref> [[J. Hoberman]] wrote that it "drove the audience mad",<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.villagevoice.com/film/hollis-frampton-at-anthology-here-there-everywhere-6389326 |title=Hollis Frampton at Anthology: Here, There, Everywhere |last=Hoberman |first=J. |authorlink=J. Hoberman |date=March 25, 2009 |website=[[The Village Voice]] |access-date=February 9, 2016}}</ref> and [[Howard Thompson (film critic)|Howard Thompson]] observed that "never, at least so far during the Film Festival, have so many Philharmonic Hall viewers slithered outside for a cigarette."<ref name="thompson-nyt"/> Nevertheless, the sale of ''Zorns Lemma'' was a financial success for Frampton.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Tuchman |first=Mitch |year=1985 |title=Frampton |journal=[[Film Comment]] |volume=21 |issue=4 |page=38}}</ref>
[[Amos Vogel]] called ''Zorns Lemma'' a "radical example of reductive cinema" that warned of "things to come ... 'meaning' (political, psychological, personal, or whatever) has been eliminated and the work exists purely for itself, demanding attention to structure, pattern, and orchestration."<ref>Vogel 1974, p. 26.</ref> [[Kevin Thomas (film critic)|Kevin Thomas]] of the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' described the film as "a thoroughly demanding but highly stimulating exercise in heightening our awareness of the possibilities of visual perception and, indeed, the ways in which we create meaning itself".<ref>{{cite news |last=Thomas |first=Kevin |date=October 8, 1974 |title=A Progression of Images |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |page=E9 }}</ref> The experimental filmmaker [[Ernie Gehr]] stated, "''Zorns Lemma'' is a major poetic work. Created and put together by a very clear eye, this original and complex abstract work moves beyond the letters of the alphabet, beyond words and beyond [[Freud]]."<ref name="hollisframpton.org">[http://hollisframpton.org.uk/zornslemma.htm ''Zorns Lemma'' at HollisFrampton.org]</ref>
Critics have interpreted [[Stan Brakhage]]'s 1972 film ''The Riddle of Lumen'' as a response to ''Zorns Lemma''.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Michelson |first=Annette |authorlink=Annette Michelson |year=1985 |title=Frampton's Sieve |journal=[[October (journal)|October]] |publisher= |issue=32 |pages=158–159}}</ref><ref>Sitney 2008, p. 261.</ref> Director [[Peter Greenaway]] has cited the film as an influence on his work, based on its illustration of how to "structure a film without necessarily using narrative".<ref>{{cite journal |last=Hagen |first=Charles |year=1990 |title=Peter Greenaway and the Erotics of Form |journal=[[Aperture (magazine)|Aperture]] |issue=121 |page=74}}</ref> Greenaway's 1973 short film ''H Is for House'' presents long lists of words beginning with the letter ''h'', and his later feature films ''[[The Draughtsman's Contract]]'' and ''[[A Zed & Two Noughts]]'' feature children reciting abecedaries.<ref>Pascoe 1997.</ref> [[Su Friedrich]] adapted the structure of ''Zorns Lemma'' for her 1990 film ''[[Sink or Swim (1990 film)|Sink or Swim]]''. Originally intending to represent each letter of the alphabet with multiple words, Friedrich ultimately used a 26-segment structure that moves in reverse alphabetical order.<ref>Sitney 2008, pp. 309–310.</ref>
''Zorns Lemma'' received three critics' votes in the 2012 ''[[Sight & Sound]]'' polls of the world's greatest films.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bfi.org.uk/films-tv-people/4ce2b6ded348a/sightandsoundpoll2012|title=Votes for Zorns Lemma (1970)|publisher=British Film Institute|accessdate=March 31, 2017}}</ref>
